content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Imagine a gorgeous, detailed graphical story. A story of goblins, dragons, wonderful lands and gorgeous colour. Imagine a story made of heroes undertaking an epic quest to protect the kingdom from a terrible menace and journeying far and wide. Now imagine that story being brought to life, animated, and you being in control of the heroes. That's Trine 2.The artwork is jaw dropping, not because of technical wizardry or the number of polygons it pushes on screen, this isn't a game that will murder your graphics card, but instead the artistry comes from attention to detail. The watercolour feel of the skies, the glorious use of colours and sweeping vistas to sell the graphical novel element, and the heroes and villains, brought to being in near hand drawn detail. Behind this rests a solid, if somewhat generic feeling soundtrack, but a narrator who really sells the atmosphere, combined with solid voice acting for each of the protagonists (and indeed, the antagonists), it helps immerse you in the game and the story as a whole.The mechanics of the game are a refinement and improvement over the original Trine, with you switching between heroes on the fly and using their respective strengths to fight and puzzle your way through various environments, however this time it feels much slicker, and much more confident in what it does, there's many points where you'll be scratching your head, only to have the light flick on with a genuine "AH HA!" moment. It's never punishingly difficult, but it's pleasantly challenging. The lack of gore and fantasy nature of the game makes it very family friendly too, older children will get a kick out of the fantasy setting, and adults will no doubt get many of the references. In this it resembles a Pixar film, a comparison I make very affectionately.Do please check this game out, it deserves your time and attention.

												This game is completely different from all other 2d games... It's like you put your headphones on, ignore everything around you and you're in a new, amazing world, full of things to discover with a facinating nature. The best part about the game is the enviroment, its beyond all other games. The details and animations are awesome. It puts you in the mood for epic battles and doing puzzles like never before. The atmosphere is a drug itself. Does have funny achievments actually worth to spend time getting, they're both fun and challenging. You can upgrade your heroes to do even more neat stuff. Also got multiplayer, cooperactive mode so you can play it with your beloved friends. I must say that this game is catchy, not addictive in a bad way, but once you get the hand of it, you really wanna play it alot. BIG shoutout to the music, it fits the game perfectly. Worth the money NO doubt. I think this game is why god invented the word 'magic'. Do yourself a favour and buy it. Yes, right now.9.5/10

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												The best thing that I like about this game, is its graphics.Every single level, character, enemies, background and platforms are well refined. Just look at the trailer and screenshots! It is exactly as pretty as the actual game itself.It is a puzzle platformer with a little bit of action in it. There are a lot of ways to tackle all the puzzles, and a lot of different approach to advance the levels.The story itself is quite interesting. The puzzles are interesting and not too overwhelming. The boss fights pose some challenge but not impossible if you get to know how to fight (or just checkpoint-abuse).The flexible difficulty settings make this game suitable for different type of player. After you defeat one playthru, you can replay all the stages from the start again with your already-unlocked skills to get past the stages in different way, and to collect the experience vials whereby you cannot collect in your first playthru.Multiplayer is best played with friends that has almost the same progress to avoid spoilers and trolling.The achievements added quite a bit of challenge and replayability if you're going for 100% completion.My score: 10/10

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game is a proof that 2D gaming is not dead at all. The game is beatiful, the artwork the colors and design.The way you have to go is linear (to the right),  but to make it there you will find a lot of puzzles and obstacles. You control 3 characters, each one with different talents to learn, and abilities to use. you will need them 3 to get through the puzzles the game presents.The game is not short, it will take you a good time to get to the end. And even if you do, you will not have unlocked all your abilities. After you finish it you will most likely try to complete it on the hard difficulty, and get all the collectibles.After you find every single collectible item, you will be able to play the locked levels.The most fun I had with the game is playing with my brothers. The online play on this game is amazing, as you will find the three characters at the same time, interacting with each other.Pros: Beautiful game amazing graphics, tricky puzzles that don't get repetitive, as they are always different. Great online play. I recommend it, as it's a very enjoyable experience.Cons: Sometimes getting through the game to find collectibles can be a pain. The game is not perfect, there are ways to 'cheat' and skip puzzles, specially on multiplayer mode. Try not to find gameplay guides and videos, they will probably show you the wrong way.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Trine 2: Complete Story Original Release: 2013 Genre Tags: Platformer; Adventure; Puzzle; Coop; Beautiful Artwork   My Overall Grade: A Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 10-25 hours Multiplayer Aspect: Optional Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Casual gamers; Multiplayer gamers REVIEWTrine 2 is the sequel to the instant classic that was the first.  And it successfully takes a big step forward from the first game in all the positive aspects.  However, not too much was changed, ensuring that the charm achieved in the first game is still prevalent. Like its forefather, Trine 2 is a light game that is easy to digest but offers gripping visuals, a mystical atmosphere, and enticing gameplay.  All of the features of the game are simple in design but intricate in execution.  The gameplay, aesthetics, and narrative all come together to create a whimsical and charming adventure.  I highly recommend this for all gamers to consider; and for fans of the genre it is a sure bet.Keeping in the tradition of the first game, the best aspects of Trine 2 are the stunning visuals and alluring atmospheric presentation of the setting. Each and every environment you explore is diverse, captivating, and charming. The ambiance really captures the mystical aura of the game perfectly. Trine 2 somehow even manages to feel even more mystical than the first, and also has one of the most immersive 2D environments in the realm of video games.The gameplay is light and quick to grasp. Anyone should be able to dive right in, regardless of ability level. But various difficulty levels and a “hardcore” mode ensure that skilled players can still find a challenge. And whether you are playing on “easy” or “hardcore,” the gameplay is entertaining. Trine 2 also offers a decent amount of increased depth to the character development aspects of the game compared to the first installment of the franchise. There are more abilities and items; and more varied strategies are needed to solve the puzzles.As a direct sequel, the whimsical narrative is continued from the first game and the endearing trio of characters return. Even though it is a direct sequel, though, the story is quite separated from the original. So it won’t be the end of the world if you haven’t played the first game; but you probably should because it is also fantastic.Also the option of playing in cooperative mode adds an additional layer of possibilities, as the unique gameplay of the Trine series is a joy to experience with friends.So like I did with the first game, I would say that Trine 2 is worthy of your consideration regardless of your standard preferences. Check it out.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
TRINE 2: COMPLETE STORYA majestic platform puzzle game with a dash of action.Rating 6/10It’s similar in many ways to the classic Shadow of the Beast series and The Lost Vikings. You take control of one of three heroes, a wizard, thief and knight, whilst being able to character swap at any time even mid jump.  It's this fluid change from styles in the middle of battle or solving a puzzle that adds another dimension to what could turn into fairly simplistic gameplay. There are times when it doesn't work such as having your thief or knight die and only being left with a wizard who is rather useless in a fight. However there are enough character reviving checkpoints that it doesn't become too much of an annoying handicap.Despite being a fairly traditional side scrolling platform game it's a truly beautifully made game, in artistic terms it's near perfect. It's this beauty coupled with the fun physics puzzles and quick action that keeps you playing as the plot is non-existent and the voice acting is weak.The DLC adds a few new environments such as dusty desert and the inside of a giant worm and whilst every bit as stunning as the main game by this stage Trine 2 has overstayed it's welcome and it's a fairly boring slog through the last seven extra levels. The DLC doesn't add any real new mechanics or gameplay, it’s just more of the same.So whilst trine 2 doesn't offer much in the way of innovative gameplay or a great story it's beauty has to be seen.

number of helpful: 36 of 39 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Trine 2 is a wonderful physics-based platformer. The levels are all well-designed and afford just the right amount of leeway to let the player figure out creative solutions to obstacles. All three heroes that the player (or players - the game has online co-op that works great) controls have unique abilities that can be combined in clever ways to traverse the environments. Sometimes it feels like you can abuse the physics engine to bypass things, but I'm pretty sure most of it is intentional, as the inverse that is often present in physics-based platformers just isn't there: you'll never feel like you came up with a solution that should have worked but got cheated because the physics went wonky. It's just the right blend of physics sandbox and puzzle game.The only real issue is the combat. It's super simple, and so long as your warrior is alive, absolutely trivial. It's perhaps best to treat enemies as just another physics toy. Fighting them hand-to-hand quickly becomes dull, but you can pick up enemies as the wizard and see how they're affected by the environment. Thankfully, it's a small enough part of the game that I don't think anyone should be dissuaded by my complaints, especially since respawning at a checkpoint doesn't reset enemies, so you never ever have to go through a fight again.On the presentation side, Trine 2 is absolutely flawless. The supersaturated graphics are utterly gorgeous. Every single frame of this game would make an excellent wallpaper. It simply is that beautiful. The audio is perfect, with great music and excellent voice work. And the story is simple but very well written and charming. Everything comes together to look, feel, and sound like a fairy tale.

												Trine 2 is a beautiful game. The gameplay overall is decent. The problem is that the gameplay is too simple and too recognizable. Puzzles are basically you levitating stuff to get to shiny balls in the air and if you are aiming for a complete playthrough that is what you are going to be doing the majority of the time, and after a while it gets to be a chore. The combat and platforming works well enough but is hardly challenging and even boring at times. If you have played Trine 1, then there's nothing new in Trine 2 except the visually pleasing looks. If you expect a beautiful standard platformer you wont be disappointed.

												What about Trine 2? The first had been great, the 2nd manages to be better in every aspect, the addition of the coop for example is a resource that matches perfectly with the game.The gameplay remains based on intelligent puzzles, but the coop gave another dynamic to the game, there was the addition of new skills to characters, as well as a greater number of enemies, a factor that was limited in the first. Fluid & boasting competent, creative platforming // A perfect fill for that jumping & puzzle-solving hole in your heart+ Narrator adds to the experience via comical injections of commentary+ Puzzles are certainly engaging; they often require a healthy mix of timing and creativity to advance beyond+ Each playable character feels unique and plays differently; each has a well-defined strength and a weakness+ Gorgeous visuals with healthy passive animation throughout the game's backdrops; color palette is widely varied and stunning in presentation+ Game offers online co-op of up to 3 people+ Game engine runs smoothly and efficiently+ Controls are crisp and intuitive+ Movement and platforming elements are well-polished- Objectives suffer occasional, inordinate spikes in difficulty- Leviation controls can sometimes prove awkward and frustratingLockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

Posted: April 22, 2015
												La version française de ce commentaire se trouve aprèsA great and very beautiful platform game: splendid graphic and animation, great music and the puzzle are could be quite challenging (not every time as some as easier than other). Also, you have some battle to go through (against goblins mostly and other kind of monster as well as boss). And to do all that you are in control of 3 different characters in 1: a mage, a thief and a warrior.Let me explain more exactly what is all about : in fact, you manage one character at the time but you always have the choice to change during the game as each one have his own strength and weakness. So to pass some of the puzzle you have to use one specific character... but you can make it more challenging and try to only use one character during the whole episode.The story itself is not the most original even if it is funny, but is quite interesting to follow and is well tell.I have not yet try the multiplayer part, but for what I have seen in some videos, you play with  one or two partners one of the hero and so you can help each other... well that could help to pass some puzzle faster and have great fun as well ;o)So to make it simple, is for me one of the best platform game of this year (2014)! I don't see the time going and have some difficulty to stop playing. Luckily, there are always a pause between the different chapter (and a quite funny one).-----------------------------Un très beau et excellent jeu de plateforme : graphismes et animations magnifiques, très belle musique et les casse-têtes peuvent être plutôt exigeant (pas tout le temps car certains sont plus faciles que d’autres). Aussi vous avez quelques combats à faire (contre des gobelins majoritairement et d’autres types de monstres ainsi que des boss). Et pour faire tout cela vous allez devoir contrôler 3 personnages différents en 1 : un mage, une voleuse et un guerrier.Laisser-moi vous expliquer exactement ce qu’il en est : en fait vous allez contrôler un personnage à la fois mais vous aurez toujours le choix de changer durant le jeu car chacun a ses forces et ses faiblesses. Donc pour passer certains casse-têtes vous devez utiliser un des héros… mais vous pouvez vous donner plus de défi en gardant le même personnage durant tout l’épisode.L’histoire en elle-même n’est pas la plus originale même si il y a pas mal d’humour elle reste intéressante à suivre et elle est bien contée.Je n’ai pas encore essayer la partie multijoueur, mais pour ce que j’en ai vu à travers plusieurs vidéos, vous jouer avec un ou deux autres joueurs un des héros et ainsi vous pouvez vous aider… en somme cela peut permettre de faire certains passages plus rapidement et pas mal s’amuser ;o)Donc pour faire simple, c’est pour moi un des meilleurs jeux de plateforme de cette année (2014) ! Je n’ai pas vu le temps passer et j’ai eu du mal à m’arrêter. Heureusement qu’il y a une pause entre les différents chapitres (et vraiment drôle avec ça).

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												Trine 2 is easily one of the most beautiful games today. It is a really addictive game, with an innovative approach to the platformer genre.The main point that makes Trine 2 so enjoyable is that it requires thought to play: you have to solve puzzle after puzzle in each screen, and eventually fight some enemies and bosses. There are plenty of bosses.Another nice thing (for me, at least) about Trine 2 is that the difficult increases gradually, but the curve is not too steep: you get a chance to learn how things work in Trine 2's world, and how your powers work. Trine 2's characters are very well designed, and they complement each other nicely, leaving nothing to be desired. All in all, Trine 2 deserves one of those Oscars for games, if there were one.  The only downside I see in Trine 2 is that some of the Steam Achievements are nearly impossible to get, but that doesn't get in the way of the game at all.I highly recommend Trine 2.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Platformers come in many shapes.Twitch-platformers and reflex-platfomers, which I can't stand, and puzzle, action, and physics platformers, which I enjoy.Trine 2 is an action-puzzle platformer, maintaining a good, steady progression flow [versus getting stuck trying to hit the same platform jump for 10 minutes, like some platformers], offering a good variety of physics, combat, and puzzle challenges.Few of these challenges will be overly demanding on you- combat especially isn't meant to hinder your progres as much as offer palate cleansing or distractions to puzzles,  But there's a lot of creativity and style in the game, and it ends up being enjoyable in the same way all the best classic [eg, nothing like Meat Boy] platformers are.PROS*Fun single-player with plenty of unlocks and secrets, that manages to keep you steadily 'just challenged enough' to make for a relaxing-yet-stimulating engagement.*Astoundingly good co-op. You thought single player was fun? Imagine being able to leverage your partner for crazy combos, reinterpret all the puzzles in new and delightfully clever ways, and, best of all? 'Accidentally' drop your partner into lava, drop a box on their head, or smash the platform they're floating on.Hey, it's what friends are for.*Co-op is easy to set up, has a decent selection of hosting options, and plays very smoothly.*Good variety of stagesStages range from small dungeon corridors, to open city or dungeon expanses, to vertical shafts, to underwater caverns, to skyscapes and more. I never found myself dissatisfied with stage progression.*Good variety of puzzles*Good variety of unlocks*Good, consistant blend of action, combat, puzzling, platforming.*Very stable (very few bugs and no major bugs)NEUTRAL*Each stage tends to emphasize the same enemies. Would have been nice if there was more variety and sub-bosses.*The expansion abilities offer tons of fun new dynamics- but can significantly reduce game difficulty.*While the stages and enemies have flair and creativity, there's no story whatsoever to speak of. Generally not something that platformer players really worry about but since this is also RPG, I'm going to make a note that's a tag based only in being able to find items to gear your characters up with, and being able to unlock/upgrade abilities.*Workshop support, but last time I checked, no legitimately decent offerings. The few that look good, tend to have a lot of bugs, like falling into or through terrain.*The characters are a bit dim. The humor here is definitely subjective, though thankfully, never offensive or intrusive [think mild 'you're so fat' and fart referencing humor].CONS*The expansion content feels like a clumsy afterthought. If you already own Trine 2, you really don't need to buy Complete Story unless you really want to play the main game again, and try the new expansion abilities in it.---This game is one of my absolute favorite co-op games, and if you're at all into co-op gaming, I can't recommend it enough.The most 'nasty' things are spike pits, carnivorous plants, skeletons, and goblins, so it should be playable with relatively young children, as the game doesn't include gore, frights, or offensive humor.4.5/5Bonus:If you like Trine 2, you may also want to give Ibb & Obb a look- it's a pure puzzle-physics platformer, so a different vibe, but it has good puzzling co-op (and is far more of a challenge for the brain than Trine 2). Do however note that there's a bug that, if not yet fixed, makes the last level unable to be completed for a small number of players.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Trine 2 is the definition of what a plaformer should be.  The graphics are top notch with great lighting.  The fluidity of the animation and controls are perfect so that while some of the puzzle sections may be difficult at times they are never blamed on the slick controls.  The levels are long enough to be enjoyable and not too long where they get boring.  Each level offers a variety of landscapes and scenery, all of which are beautiful.  The storyline is forgettable, but still sets up a good reason for why you are playing the game.  The three different characters offer very different ways of playing and each offer different ways to solve the puzzles.  Think of it as an action only version of Quest for Glory where each character has a different solution to each puzzle.  The addition of the Goblin Menace, the Dwarven Carverns and now the Workshop has helped expand and continue the gameplay of this fabulous series.  The best part of this game is the multiplayer offering.  Now with online multiplayer, this game truly shines when playing with two or more players.The price for this game, when on sale is typically under $4 for the entire complete story.  Take advantage and don't miss this great game.  Bound to be a classic in gaming history.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												After the release of Trine 3 which is considered a mixed bag it is high time I reviewed the sequel which is better in every which way than its predecessor.The premise remains the same in the 2nd episode of Frozenbyte's amazing franchise: the mysterious object called Trine binds 3 heroes together who all have different abilities and gameplay style. In terms of story they have switched from skeletons to goblins. Not much of a change but you know it's all about saving the kingdom once more. We have the same 3 characters from the first episode and in terms of timeline we are a couple of years after the events of Trine 1.What shines in Trine 2 is its graphics. Not that the first one was ugly, quite the contrary! Still, they managed to make the game even more beautiful (the water effect is stunning). In fact, the first game was updated with the sequel's engine and it is now only available in Enhanced Edition version.Overall, the gameplay remains the same but they have tweaked it a bit here and there. For instance, the wizard cannot conjure floating triangles but can pick up monsters. The heroes all received some new abilities and each now seems to be more useful. And, of course, we have some puzzles that utilise physics and have to be solved accordingly.The longevity of the game has also increased. Levels are more complex and much bigger. There are tons of collectibles to find - poems in treasure chests and also paintings (no equipment, though). You'll probably not be able to collect them all in one go! And let us not forget about the achievements - there's now a threefold increase. I believe Trine 2 is an example as to how a sequel should be done. For fans of the first one it is a must and for those hating the 3rd (and preferably last) a revisit has been due for some time. The game also features proper multiplayer i.e. it is not LAN anymore.

number of helpful: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												The indie games market became a very good alternative for the young game developers willing to step up in their careers. And I’m not only saying this because many of the games I am talking about are truly masterpieces of their genre from any point of view. On the contrary. Fun characters, divine graphics- the starting point for an impressive gameplay. Still, I never would have thought that a sequel was going to animate my screen and I couldn’t have been more wrong about it.  Trine 2 is here, I’ve played it and, since I’m a hard-working guy, here’s a very meticulous review.Same as the first game, the three heroes, The Wiseman, The Knight and The Thief…pardon me, I meant The “Inventive woman” are united by a magical artifact called The Trine, whose goal is to protect the land from a new threat. Therefore, the inevitable goblin infestation. So, the three characters are up for a new adventure which, unlike the first game, takes a little longer time to play.In a very bizarre way, Trine 2 makes me think of Terry Pratcher’s novels, maybe because of its strange atmosphere that I picked up by reading this author’s books. The Universe presented in this title is so subtle that you can only be overwhelmed with its complexity. Even if it is an Indie game that we are talking about, the narrative value can not be ignored since this time, the characters are better shaped by their developers, humanized I might say, from the voiceover’s point of view as well as from the action’s point of view. I will even go further and say that Trine 2 offers a very pleasant story for all ages, even if it’s a 12+ game, precisely because the narration has something to offer to everyone. Nostalgic to say at least! Still, there are some missing bricks to this wall. The key of this story is nice indeed, but the main problem is the poor narrative construction. I think everybody would have been happier if someone would have added some solid touches to this aspect. The motivations are clear, meaning that the land is full of goblins, but the story as a whole concept could have been more complex. Who knows, maybe Trine 3 will surprise me when the time comes. The three key-elements that a player must take into consideration when starting this game are : cooperation, cleverness and physics. These elements are as important as the three main characters. Even if, on a regular basis, Trine 2 is a platformer, these elements are very necessary while dealing with a certain level. At the beginning of the game, there is a tutorial to teach you what every character can do. The Wiseman, because he is your starting point, is not the every-day Gandalf that everyone got used to. He is more of a clumsy magician for he has no idea what a fire ball really is. Still, he has his own tips and tricks, he can make objects appear from nowhere, such as boxes, or even make them levitate to get to certain locations. The Knight, on the other hand, is the muscled genius among the three characters. Even if he’s not very bright, he’s compensating by his strength, also being the best choice when it comes to a one on one fight with your enemies. Equipped with a shield, a hammer and a sword, he’s the defensive one of the trio. Last but not least, The Thief. And no, you’re not going to break chains or sneak behind your enemies, because her abilities are more rogue-like. She has a hook to reach to certain points otherwise inaccessible and an elastic loop to fight at the distance. What’s truly interesting and new is the way you switch between these characters to complete a level. The puzzles are sometimes so twisted that they really work your cleverness off! But that doesn’t mean there’s only one way to deal with a puzzle. Frozenbyte finally made it with this platformer: the experience is multidimensional, despite of its puzzle-platformer prejudices. To solve a certain puzzle, the player has at least three ways, which is pretty unexpected among the game mechanics that other developers use.  The characters’ control is absolutely beautiful. After pressing a key or a button if you’re playing on a controller, the task is immediately registered by your game. This is one of the most satisfying platformers I’ve played since Sonic Generations. No platformer fanatic could ever find a misstep concerning this aspect. The game control is perfect, I would say.Trine 2 is not only made of twisted puzzles, but also of battle sequences and a handful of bosses every now and then. These fights are meant to break the monotony of a certain level, full of enigmas. Still, the gameplay is so rewarding that the player can use his characters’ abilities to knock down the enemies. And because something had to be done when it came to options, each hero has a set of five abilities that can be improved using the experience points you get. What I find extremely stressful is that some of the abilities you get using this tree are only necessary for a specific level. The player has to reassign some of his points in order to finish a portion of the puzzle. I must say that this procedure is free, so you don’t have to repeat anything to get more experience afterwards. One of the major gains of this game is the cooperative multi-player, online and local, a huge step from the previous game and probably one of the reasons for which we strongly recommend a bundle. Two more players can be added to one session, each one of them being able to control in an active way one of the three characters, which makes the puzzles a lot easier, as far as I’m concerned. That being said, I must admit that I found myself playing this game even for the third time, just because it’s fun to find new ways to complete a level: a very nice move coming from Frozenbyte, although Zon@ thinks they should have done this from the beginning. We are finally getting to graphics. Did I mention this is an Indie game that comes from a small studio where are working about 20 people? Well, Trine 2 is a masterpiece of beauty. Want to hear something more spectacular that this? The game engine has been totally reconstructed. The game not only that looks divine, but its physics is very accurate. From the well animated background to the small details , nothing has been left out. And everything is the work of a very small, but talented, team. I know it sounds like I’m trying to get under their skin, but I’m telling the truth. The animations, the flow, the light and all the other elements gave me the impression that I was watching a moving painting. The colours also made a huge impression on me, one I will not easily forget. The sound itself is quite an experience. Not only that the narrative part is well represented on script, but the voices and the entire performance of the characters are as authentic as they could be. It sounds just like a very posh movie. The soundtrack is exactly what the game needed to complete the atmosphere: the way it highlights the key points of the game makes your blood rush and your adrenaline keep pumping which turns the whole experience into a sound feast.  Is Trine 2 a good game? I’ve been praising it a lot so yes, it is! It’s one of those games you have to play in order to find out what a creative genius really means. If the first game managed to get my attention, Trine 2 has upgraded to a very high standard among platformers.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
Trine 2: Complete StoryIf you liked the first, odds are you'll love the second. What did it for me was the visuals—they're even more breathtakingly enchanting than the first instalment of the series and that was enough to make me want to keep playing. The gameplay felt very similar to the original title, although that wasn't really an issue for me: not much of an attempt to improve, but then why try to fix what ain't broke. The story is the low point in my opinion, and felt like it was just there to feed lines to the characters and narrator—who are all still doing a great job.Pros:Visuals are even more detailed, gorgeous and immersive; Clever, slightly more challenging physics-based puzzles;Fantasy creatures on a larger scale;Build-up to boss fights increases anticipation;Gameplay adapts to your play-style;Casual base, yet deceptively intricate mechanics;Soundtrack and VO are true to the first instalment;Goblin Menace DLC adds a bit of much needed length;Co-op doubles the fun.Neutral:New upgrades are original and fun, but ultimately aren't enough to change/improve core gameplay in a significant way.Cons:Uninspired story and collectibles;Trine 3 advertisement each time you quit the game;

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
IntroTrine 2 is a amazing looking game with great dialogue thoughout the game which are its best features. There are three characters to choose from and a ton of collectables in the game.Good Points The grathics look great with bright colours and amazing visuals, Each level looks diffrent from the last so you wont get bored of the looks. Controls for Thrine 2 are simple and easy to remember, if you dont like using a keybored and mouse then you can use a controller since it has full controller support. Trine 2 runs very well which means almost any computer will be able to run the game. If your still not sure then you can play the demo to make sure it runs alright. There is a bit of replay value, you can can play the game on hard mode or you can try and find all the secrets and get all of the   achievements which arnt so hard. The dialogue and Narrators are great and fit in with the game perfectly. Some times they can moke you laugh and sometime they make you think. There is a co-op option which is great fun with a freind which makes the experience even better. I would recommend you play Trine 2 with a freind. Being able to choose from three diffrent characters is a great idea becasue you wont get bored of the gameplay since you can just swich to a diffrent character. Its very useful to solve puzzles.Bad Points The storyline is... Rubbish. Its a simple "kill the bad guys to save the world from evil" style which has been done so many times and they done nothing to spice it up. You end up not giving a damm half way though the game. I find the game to be easy, really easy. There are puzzles in every level but you end up solving them in seconds. The enemies are the same from biggining to end and since you level up, it becomes easy. The game time is short. You can complete it in about 5 hours if you dont collect or find secrets. If you want to find the secrets and take things slowly then it will take about 7 to 8 hours.OverallOverall I think Trine 2 is a good game which is fun to play with freinds. But its easy to move on to diffrent games. You will most likely end up forgetting about it once you have finished the game. I would recomment Trine 2 if you want to play it with a freind and if you like good looking games. I rate Trine 2 7 out of 10.

												Trine 2 is the same as Trine (1) and keeps the story of our three heroes on. You (as the player) can switch ingame between the wizard, the knight and the thief. All three got their own specialties and you switch characters on spot (so one disappears from screen and is replaced by the other).I think that the big success of the game is exactly that thing. number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Frozenbyte continues the legacy of the original Trine in this worthwhile sequel as the game features many of the same trademarks that made the first so successful. Trine 2 plots a new story and setting that takes full advantage of the developer's creative prowess. This action/adventure platformer maintains its unique perspective on the classic genre and revitalizes to modern standards. Any casual gamer armed with a good controller will find themselves lost in world of Trine given its clever structure, voice-acting and detailed fantasy world. It should be noted that Trine 2 features a downloadable content pack called "Trine 2: Goblin Menace" that is played as a separate campaign.The Goblin Menace downloadable content (DLC) is a worthwhile expansion for Trine 2 that unveils a variety of new settings with increasing difficulty. The story is rather simple, but stems directly from the sequel so the plot seems like a true continuation of the original game. Fans of the Trine series owe it to themselves to purchase and play through the Goblin Menace!

												I finished the "Complete Story" version of Trine2, which is an extended version of the regular Trine2. The extra content ("Gobling Menace DLC") is almost of the same size as the original, and it's equally nice, maybe even prettier! It took me about 13hrs to beat the whole game, and it wasn't particularly difficult, especially when you get the hang of it.GameplayIt's essentially a puzzle platform game, with a bit of action (battles) at some points. You have three characters (fighter, mage & rogue archetypes) that you switch to any time during play; each character has unique abilities that will help you get through the various puzzles you come across. Each level of the game (there are about 20 levels for the "Complete Story") has about 10-15 puzzles to complete, with save/checkpoints every one or two. Most puzzles are typically "get to the right of the screen" type, over chasms or mechanisms or beating foes, and can usually be solved in a multitude of different ways. The puzzles weren't too challenging, and some of them might be a little repetitive, i.e. you could easily go through them using "standard" techniques. There's also hints to get you going, if you're stuck on a puzzle for too long. I played with WASD keys + mouse, and there are also some more keyboard shortcuts; controls were quite simple to learn & master and I encountered no problem. No glitches or weird bugs fell to my attention, and the physics engine of the game was quite robust.Theme/Graphics/SoundThe story is all set in a fairy-tale world, which some might find a bit "underaged" (as if it's meant for children, i.e. far from "mature"), but I didn't mind that so much. The graphics are ASTOUNDING, computer-made but beautiful, and fleshed in 3D even if the game is essentially 2D. Lighting and other visual effects are particularly well done and there's some pretty animations at the end of each level. There's a great variety of "worlds" you're going to have to go through: from dark dungeons to ice-caverns, to jungles, to deserts, to floating-islands, even to the belly of a giant beast! Each is rendered in a very pretty and unique style. The three heroes (along with the narrator and some other characters) are very well voiced, all along the story and at each level. The music is nice too, although I can't state anything special about it.My OpinionRecommended, if you like puzzle-platform games that aren't too difficulty. The graphics are also a BIG plus to this game. You might wanna pass this, if you don't like fairy-tale settings or puzzles :)

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												"Beauty is power; a smile is its sword."Trine 2 represents a 2-D jump & run adventure game with impressive artwork, beautiful design and sophisticated puzzles. As already introduced in the original Trine you can switch on the fly between three different characters, a knight, thief and wizard (still no fireballs). It is also the basis for the great puzzle system this game offers, and the multitude of possibilities to solve each one of them.The balance between combat and puzzle sections leave no room for boredom. And the adjustable level of difficulty gives newcomers and veterans a fair chance to prove their abilities. Furthermore the multiplayer adds some extra life to the game, as the experience is genuinely different.The DLC in form of Goblin Menace adds a couple new levels, a new story, and several new skills which will also be available in the original game.Overall Trine 2 feels more refined than its predecessor and the beautiful artwork in combination with the creative puzzle sections are very persuasive and entertaining. In addition it offers enough content to justify itself as a worthy sequel to Trine.Fun fact: Due to relatively poor sales for Trine 2 on Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, the conversion for the expansion for these consoles was deemed not be cost effective, thus Trine 2: Goblin Menace was never released for these platforms.--My rating system consists of five categories in descending order of importance:-	Atmosphere -	Details-	Puzzles-	Story-	Combat & ControlsBased on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading: -	S-Rank: excellent-	A-Rank: very good-	B-Rank: solid-	C-Rank: satisfactory-	D-Rank: inferiorIf the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).--Atmosphere: A-RankDetails: S-Rank(It's not what you look at that matters, it's what you see.)Puzzles: S-Rank(To improve is to change; to be perfect is to change often.)Story: B-RankCombat & Controls: A-Rank [with a gamepad]--To conquer all achievements of Trine 2, you will most likely spend around 40 hours. There are several multiplayer achievements, which can be easily obtained with two people.Should you have any questions about the different achievements, please feel free to contact me.Achievement difficulty: 6 of 10Common:Singleplayer [+1]Multiplayer [+1]DLC [+1]Special:Trine 2 Hard [+1]Trine 2 Hard II [+1]Trine Kaput For Good? 												First thing I noticed was that this game has very beautiful graphics. It is a 2D platformer, but it looks so dynamic and magical. 												26-Aug-2016 : Finished main story + extrasSetup : Windows 10 64-Bit, MSI GT80-2QE Notebook, Logitech F710 GamepadREVIEW :I have mixed feeling about this game. I love the first one, but this one... it's like the developer hates the players and just want to make our gameplay miserable. The thing that I hate most about Trine 2 level design are "slippery when wet". This slippery floor make it impossible to backtrack to get missed collectibles, you either have to restart from checkpoint or restart the level entirely (if you're playing hardcore mode). The collectibles are a lot more than the 1st game and some of them are in really hidden and challenging position, but the not so fluid control make it really frustrating to get them.Other than that, like the 1st game, it has beautiful graphics and music. The story is mediocre, more like children story. Since it has multiplayer up to 3 players, I guess it's a good family game to play with your siblings or children (if you're a parent). CONCLUSION :Recommended on sale price.

content:
Posted: January 14
												There's something special about the Trine games. They combine the best parts of artistic design and exploration for the sake of beauty with a thinking mans puzzle mechanics which can be combined and utilised in interesting and unexpected ways. Along with fantastic extras like co-op, challenges and the likes (all of which are actually worth trying out and fun in their own rights) this is one of the games I've loved from the moment I first picked up.As for the rest of the series, Trine 1 holds a special place in my heart because I picked it up first and because it set the bar so high, but Trine 2 raises the bar and takes nothing away- it's prettier, it has more content, it's more responsive and technically improved and it's just an all round improvement, and then Trine 3, while I appreciate it a lot more than most despite its failings is still the lesser of the three.Picking up the whole series is absolutely my recommendation, but if you only have time for one, Trine 2 is my suggestion.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												I have to say that I was much more happy with this game than the first one, and that is simply because I was able to play online co-op with a friend. The whole premise isn't necessarily original, but the levels you go through are pretty interesting, and it is so enjoyable to plan things out with a friend as you are playing along, accomplishing the puzzles.Some of them took us a good while to accomplish - some because they were actually hard, and some because we simply missed something and would feel stupid afterwards. But that's why I liked this game so much more than the first, because I had a friend to talk to that gave a different perspective. Neither of us one-sided the game, meaning that both of us were able to give our perspectives on what we were supposed to do - it wasn't like one of us had all of the answers.Further, both of us easily assigned ourselves roles: I was the thief, and my friend was the wizard (sorry, knight, you're not exactly that useful unless you're absolutely needed!) and we got through the game in one sitting. Playing the first game got sad because things are much more annoying to accomplish on your own in the puzzles, and I simply don't think it's as fun.So would I recommend the game? Yes. Great graphics, some nice humor to the premise, nice little puzzles and levels. But definitely make sure you have somebody to play it with!

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Trine 2 is a very fun and challenging little game that features both singleplayer and coop! I find the game to be much more enjoyable to play with two friends, but it's completely fine to play it by yourself too.In Trine 2 there is three characters availible to play as, Pontius the Knight, Amadeus the Wizard and Zoya the Thief. Every character has its own attributes that is needed to complete the puzzles and continue through the levels. In singleplayer mode you can switch between all three characters when you need to, and in coop every player plays one character.In the first game your heroes saved the kingdom from an undead invasion, after that the heroes separated and lived their own lives, until now. The Trine warps the trio to a mysterious place that they have never heard of or seen before. The three heroes slowly discover the path out of this mysterious place while someone is observing their progress through a magic mirror...There is also a DLC called "The Goblin Menace". If you are unsure if you want to buy this game, I can totally recommend it! I've had tons of fun playing this with my friends, was it laughing at eachothers deaths and ridiculous ragdolls or trying to figure out the puzzles, finding "cheaty" ways to skip the puzzle and try to get to the next part of the level.The DLC adds quite a few more levels of gameplay and an amusing storyline which was very enjoyable!I recommend this game to anyone! Especially if you have two friends to play it with. And while at it, why not get the DLC and have even more fun?

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Trine 2 is a side-scrolling action platform and puzzle video game developed by Frozenbyte. It is the sequel to Trine and was released on Windows, OS X, PlayStation Network and Xbox Live Arcade on December 7, 2011 and for Linux on March 31, 2012. Trine 2 allows three players to play the iconic roles of a wizard, a thief, and a knight in a simultaneous cooperative mode. A Director's Cut edition was confirmed during Nintendo's conference at E3 2012, and was available via Wii U's eShop on the console's launch day in all regions except Australia and Japan.The Director's Cut edition is Frozenbyte's first self-published title on a console format, although this edition will be released by Nintendo themselves in Japan on January 2014. On October 28, 2013 it was announced via the PlayStation Blog that Trine 2: Complete Story will be coming to PlayStation 4.It was released as a launch title for the PlayStation 4 in North America and Europe. It's the first PlayStation 4 game to support stereoscopic 3D.Trine 2 is a puzzle platform video game, requiring the player to use the skills of the three characters, Amadeus the wizard, Zoya the thief, and Pontius the knight, to navigate each game level. As with the first game, the mystical "Trine" has bound the three characters together into one common entity, and thus the player controls only one character which can be switched to the other two at any time. Each of the characters has unique abilities: Amadeus can use magic to grab onto certain objects in the game world, and create boxes and planks to be used to get around; Zoya can strike at objects with her arrows, and grapple onto certain surfaces; and Pontius is strong in combat against foes, can bash apart walls, and deflect projectiles with his shield. A combination of these elements is necessary to complete each stage in the game's world.Characters have individual life meters, and if one character's meter depletes, that character cannot be used until the next checkpoint is reached. If all three characters lose their life meter, the player must start back at the last checkpoint. Throughout the game world are special magical vials, and for every fifty of these collected, the player receives a skill point, which can be used to gain abilities through a skill tree for each character. These skill points can be used collectively for each of the three characters, and can be traded between them.Trine 2 also supports up to three players in a cooperative mode. In this mode, each player controls one of the three characters, but all must be unique; three players will be forced to play as Amadeus, Zoya, and Pontius. Two players can switch characters as long as both agree to the swap. If a character dies, the other players can revive the character at the next checkpoint. The skill tree is shared among all characters, based on the hosting player's saved game.Rate: 10/10

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												When did gaming culture love graphics more than content? This game right here. This game is the perfect example of how you can make a turd of a game, then make it look pretty and everyone will love it. Other than that there are no saving graces what-so-ever. The story line, is the most cookie cutter thing you can imagine. "We need to save the princess." -> That's the entirety of the plot. The characters are bland and boring. Each of the three main characters, are about as cookie cutter as you can get. The interactions between the characters offers no additional story or plot mechanic to make you care about any of the events or personal ramifications of their quest.Gameplay, terrible. Just terrible. Can you press the RB button on a controller? Yes, then you will destroy this game no problem, even on hard. Spam the mage abilities to solve the "puzzles" (this term is used to a looser degree than my mom), it really is that easy. When in battle, just switch to either the warrior or rogue, fight off the enemies, of which there is really only 1 type with a couple variations, then switch back and run forward. With all the "hints" turned off from the beginning, I never once got stuck on a "puzzle" for longer than 45 seconds. Don't buy this game, it's just a turd that was spray painted gold. The last boss of the main game, I laughed when it was over because it was so bad. I would rather sit through the last hour of Mass Effect 3 again, than buy another Trine game... Fact, not fiction.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2012
												Usually with 2D platformers, you're given an obstacle with one answer on how to solve it.  Trine has been that exceptional, and very beautiful 2D platformer that allows you to create your own solutions to the level obstacles ahead.  With Trine 2, not only has the difficulty increased, but it now allows for online co-op where three friends can take control of each of the three characters, creating the new challenge of how to get everyone across the obstacles together.  This is a wonderful game to play with your two closest friends that can also provide quite a laugh when your friends formulate plans that look far too dumb to work and then it actually succeeds.  When you find you or your friends saying, "wow, was I supposed to do that?" you just know a game like this is truly the refresher that the 2D platformer needed, even for people who didn't originally care for the genre.  I would easily recommend this game, especially for the $15 price tag.  Hell, I'd have paid $30!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Take control of three bound together heroes in the beautiful second installment of the Trine series, each hero filling a specific role required for progressing which means it's a perfect for playing alone, switching between the characters when necessary, or if you want a real challenge, play a character each with a couple of friends and see just how much you begin to depend on one another. :P In my opinion, Trine 2 is a wonderful improvement from the first game as it removes a few unnecessary restrictions, has some mild gameplay improvements, and improves drastically in general quality introducing some stunning backdrops and soundtracks, the only thing I felt was lacking was uses for the Warrior, unfortunately he seemed to have more of a role in the first game as there'd be plenty more enemies for him to smash away at, but trust me, if you enjoy fantasy, action, and puzzles, you'll want in on this adventure. ;)

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2012
												Usually with 2D platformers, you're given an obstacle with one answer on how to solve it.  Trine has been that exceptional, and very beautiful 2D platformer that allows you to create your own solutions to the level obstacles ahead.  With Trine 2, not only has the difficulty increased, but it now allows for online co-op where three friends can take control of each of the three characters, creating the new challenge of how to get everyone across the obstacles together.  This is a wonderful game to play with your two closest friends that can also provide quite a laugh when your friends formulate plans that look far too dumb to work and then it actually succeeds.  When you find you or your friends saying, "wow, was I supposed to do that?" you just know a game like this is truly the refresher that the 2D platformer needed, even for people who didn't originally care for the genre.  I would easily recommend this game, especially for the $15 price tag.  Hell, I'd have paid $30!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Trine 2 is a sidescrolling game that includes jumping, puzzle solving and fighting, all in a pleasant and well measured mixture.Game looks nice, style is childishly charming and fanciful, in line with it's fairytale theme.Player takes control of one of the three characters - a knight, a thief and a wizard - and freely changes between them during the adventure, using various abilities available to each one and combining them to overcome obstacles, be they botomless pitfalls, weird contraptions or enemies.Gameplay is smooth and fun, game is fairly easy and causes little to no frustration but there's still a hefty dose of satisfaction when you manage to reach some hard to notice collectible crammed in a niche in the ceiling or a hidden chest after using up a trick or two. Levels are fairly diverse, from bread and butter enchanted forests or dungeons, to walled towns under assault to really cool and weird stuff such as being inside a sand worm's digestion system.I unfortunately haven't tried multiplayer as of yet.I haven't played anything of this sort since childhood times of Prehistorik and Prince of Persia in the early 1990ies, so I don't have much modern first hand experience for comparison. However Trine 2 (as well as Trine) left me very pleasantly surprised after I got it due to a random urge to buy something on a discount. Being used to "serious" games such as aviation simulators, rpgs, Total War series, raiding mmos, Eve online etc in the recent decade(s) I remembered how it felt to play games when I was a kid and I must say the change of pace is welcome.All in all, I can recommend Trine 2. I imagine children would love it, while some of us older warhorses used to dark fantasy, dark science fiction, serious modern warfare etc can find a welcome break in this little gem.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2012
												Trine 2 follows up the original game with everything one could have hoped for in a follow-up: more variety (in combat, enemies and environments), more beautiful graphics (which I did not think was even possible), and last but not least, support for online co-op multiplayer! Simply put - it is the perfect sequel. Everything that was great about the first game (refer to my previous recommendation for details) is still great in Trine 2, if not better. Other notable changes include boss fights and the removal of the limiting "magic meter" mechanic of the original. The story this time around is also pretty neat and the same humorous banter between the three characters is on display. The game is extremely fun to play with a friend or two online, but it is definitely also worth playing solo, if that's all you can manage. In summary, Trine 2 is an all-around amazing game, and the price is right too. Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
  TL;DR  : Trine 2 is a platformer / puzzle game, and is one of the best coop games I've played. The game is gorgeous and runs very well, but the story is quite meh imo. Story / SettingReally wasn't the best part of the game, I'm not into these stereotypical RPG game stories. The characters and dialogues can be fun sometimes, but that's it. Maybe I wasn't paying attention, but I feel like the game doesn't even explain what the Trine is, and the backstory simply wasn't interesting. The content of the hidden chests disapointed me every time, but well, at least I got the achievements that went with it. GameplayThe game really shines when you're playing with someone, online or localy like I did. It can be fun alone but cooperating with someone makes it way better, wether its for the puzzles or for the combat. The only issue can be the point of view when playing multi, its not always easy to see some areas where things can be hidden, but it might be the same in single player which I haven't tried. Overall the game is easy, a few puzzles took us a few minutes but that's it. If you really want to find everything in this game it'll be more about looking everywhere than solving hard puzzles. Some entrances can be hard to find. The fact that you can just rearange the skills of your characters made it a bit too easy as well. Same thing with the respawn system, you can die on and on and on and respawn a few meters behind, whereas the enemies keep all the damage you've done to them. Some achievements are a bit harder and were the only real challenges in this game, but all of them were fun to get. PerformanceWonderful graphics, even for 720p mid quality. it runned at 30 fps with these setttings which was enough for me in a game like this one (no need for high response time or super smooth gameplay like in a FPS)Style / Graphics It was probaly the best looking game I've been able to play on my laptop. Every map or areas is full of great lightning, creatures, buildings... etc.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -   TL;PL  : Trine 2 est un platformer, et est un des meilleurs jeu coop auquel j'ai pu jouer. Le jeu est magnifique et tourne bien, même si l'histoire n'etait pas très intéressante. HistoireClairement pas le meilleur élement du jeu, ce genre d'histoire de RPG stéreotypées sont assez lourdes. Les dialogues et les personnages sont marrants parfois, mais c'est tout. Peut-être que je n'ais pas fait attention, mais je crois que le jeu n'explique même pas ce qu'est le Trine. Le contenu des coffres etait décevant à chaque fois, mais bon au moins ça permet d'obtenir des succès. GameplayIl faut vraiment jouer au jeu en multijoueur pour l'apprecier complétement, que ce soit en ligne ou localement comme j'ai fait. Ca peut etre sympa tout seul mais le fait de coopérer avec quelqu'un rends le jeu milles fois mieux, que ce soit pour les puzzles ou les combats. Le seul problème en multi est le point de vue de la camera, c'est pas toujours facile de voir certaines zones à l'ecran, où certains objets peuvent être cachés, mais c'est peut-être la même chose en un joueur. Globalement le jeu est vraiment facile, certains puzzles nous ont pris quelques minutes mais pas plus. Pour tout trouver dans ce jeu, c'est plus une question de regarder partout que de résoudre des puzzles compliqués. Certaines entrées peuvent être vraiment difficiles à trouver. Le fait que l'on peut simplement changer les compétences que l'on a assignés aux personnages rend également le jeu un peu trop facile. Pareil avec le système de respawn, on peut mourrir autant de fois qu'on veut et réapparaitre un peu derrière, alors que les ennemis gardent tous les dégats infligés. Certains succès etaient compliqués et ont été le seul vrai challenge du jeu, mais tous les succès sont sympas à obtenir. PerformanceLes graphismes sont supers beaux, meme en 720p et qualité moyenne. Le jeu tourne à 30 fps avec ces options ce qui est assez pour ce genre de jeu à mon avis (pas besoin d'un temps de réponse très rapide ou de gameplay très fluide, comme dans un FPS)Style / Graphismes Probablement le plus beau jeu auquel j'ai pu jouer sur mon portable. Chaque map a de supers effets de lumières, et de très beaux batiments et créatures.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Frozenbyte did it again, best 2D/3D sidescrolling platformer become the bestest!if you haven't play Trine before, you should be, the story about those 3 hero hook up with Trine 2.but if you just skip the first one it's not a big deal tho, not much different. Trine Reviewhere my review link for Trine, since there's not much different for the second Trine, Trine review still legit for this one.I'll just review the different between those 2, I differentiated it to positive and negative, since it's my opinion you may not agree with me with some points. here it is :+ New type of puzzle, not like the first one that concentrate on destroying, opening gate with lever, grappling platform to platform. In Trine 2 really test your cunning eyes and sense, play with waterfall, bubble, and else!+ Removal of floating triangle is a beast, now it's not a Thief-centered-puzzle-solving anymore since Zoya can't grapple to any of Wizard hand made box or planks.+ Pontius got a big buff and become more dependable in fight and puzzle solving, now he can jump farther with charge jump, and range attack with throwing hammer.+ Amadeus now can levitating enemy, so now he can be used for fighting while Zoya or Pontius not available. It's a big buff for him, not like on the first Trine, when your attacking hero both dies you'll ♥♥♥♥ed up if surrounded by enemy with Amadeus.+ Despite of increase damage of fire arrow, level 2 skill give Zoya explosion, it's a good nerf altogether with buff, it's done a little improved damage and makes take down enemy from afar much more harder.+ Reworked fire arrow projectile and damage. damage now based on how long you stretched your bowstring, not just 2 spam fire arrow attack can kill almost everything. and the fire arrow projectile now same like normal arrow, not boosted speed like before.- The first thing you'll notice is there's no Energy consumption in Trine 2, so there's no energy vial to be sure. In my opinion, removal of energy consumption makes this games a little bit easier. apparently, you can use unlimited fire arrow and levitating.- Zoya can't shoot grapple below 45degree shooting angle, it's a little bit annoying. whilst in Trine you can shoot below that point- removal of individual skill points, em-em, yes it makes the entire gameplay of Trine 2 become harder, you may not miss every single exp vial since gaining skill point is a tough job.- There's no equipable item anymore in Trine 2, so you can't modify each hero more farther just like before. I really don't understand why they remove this feature. Now hidden boxes just give you secret, artwork, or piece of letters. d'oh.TL;DRBest 2D/3D platformer I've ever played! the gameplay, story, graphic, it all absolutely perfect.It is obviously better than Trine, but that not makes you skip the first one, since they offer you different type of puzzle (not much).

 A compelling game, that is at the forefront of the genre Genre: Puzzle PlatformerYea!-Gorgous Graphics-Multiple ways to pass each puzzle-lots of collectables to be had for 100%Meh!-Character Interaction and Story-Nice and simple combatBleh!-Same as Trine 1, not really anything added-Length, wish it was longer(will pick up DLC in future)The LowdownA nice and easy going puzzle platformer which is very forgiving. There are multiple solutions to every puzzle from swinging accross to making boxes to jump over. COmbat really is not a hidderance and mostly just there to break up the puzzles, which is not a bad thing at all. The game's art asthetics are just gorgous, the backgrounds are simply amazingly detailed, which you just have to be amazed by. There are tons of achievements to achieve if you are into that as well as many hidden objects to collect in each level for the scavenger. While not necessary a bad thing the game is more of an expansion to Trine 1, with not adding any new elements. But Trine 1 did everything great so its great they didn't tweak with the formula that works. AT about 7 hours it is a short game without the DLC, but I do plan on picking that up sometime in the future.Verdict: BUY IT [/b]

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												Gameplay 8/10:Each of the three playable characters comes with a satisfying and well-balanced kit, though after a few upgrades, synergistic puzzle-skipping patterns emerge. So, in a sense, levelling up is being punished by making the puzzle elements of the game less challenging. The same can't be said for the combat elements since the game offers two difficulty sliders that can provide a fair challenge to any team, pulling thus the genre shift known as this-is-a-great-platformer-oh-no-it's-a-beat-em-up.Plot 5/10:A scarcely noteworthy plot that should have been better, considering the craftsmanship that went into this game.Character 3/10:The heroes all suffer from caricature syndrome. The Trine is underdeveloped. The woman is what, a queen or something? The goblin king is a baddie. The other final boss likes to kidnap old ladies and suffers from asthma? I don't know.Diction 7/10:Though at some points it can ring false, it maintains qualities suitable to the characters.Melody 7/10:The only grievance one would have with the soundtrack is repetition. You got yer battle music, yer boss music, yer exploration music, and that's 'bout it, I reckon.Spectacle 10/10:This game is the absolute definition of beauty. Forget the gradual polycount increase you see in tech demos that add gameplay as an afterthought. Forget the pseudo-artistic vomit that comprises of nothing but dark silhouettes or blocky sprites that preys on the clueless hipster. Here is a very finely crafted and detailed game world that comes alive, despite only utilizing two dimensions of space.Final verdict:It's the quintessential 3-way co-op side-scrolling puzzle platformer/beat-em-up on PC. Do not settle for imitation products; buy Trine 2 today!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												This is coming from someone who never played (or heard of) the first Trine and played with a friend on the Medium difficulty. I’ve played it a bit in single player before doing that, and I wasn’t terribly impressed with it.Trine 2 is basically a playable fairytale; it’s not a very interesting story, but it’s set in a very charming and magical world. The playable cast are the traditional Mage-Warrior-Thief combo, but they each are quite charming in their own way (like the world of Trine itself). Amadeus (the Mage) can create boxes and planks, Pontius (the Warrior) is a great fighter and can use his shield to both fly and protect himself and his allies, and Zoya (the Thief) is, quite refreshingly, an archer with lots of nifty tricks up her sleeves. All three are rather stereotypical: Amadeus is a smart coward scared of his wife, Pontius is a gluttonous stereotypical hero more concerned with food and saving princesses and Zoya is a shifty, greedy woman. Sadly, they don’t seem to really interact all that much during the game except during moments where the player has little (if any) control. It’s a shame because the personalities clash so much that it makes for some fairly amusing dialogue.I can happily say that while this game is a sequel to Trine, it never feels like you missed anything. Sure, there are some little references to it (as far as I can tell, at least), but it’s a standalone story in its own right. Sure, it’s nothing special to begin with, but it’s refreshing to play a little fairytale instead of this big complex story with multiple plot twists. It took my friend and I about 8 hours to finish the main game (I’ll edit this when we do the DLC) and it never was too hard, though I would recommend playing on Classic and not Unlimited, as that really does force you to work together and not independently. However, I would also highly recommend playing the game with two players instead of three or one for reasons I’ll delve into later.This is mainly a puzzle game where you have to find a way to go from point A to point B with all the tools given to you, such as boxes, pipes, fire, portals and more. However, there are a TON of hidden little nooks and crannies scattered throughout the game, and since it’s mainly EXP (because yes, there is a levelling system), it’s actually rewarding in a concrete way. There are also hidden paintings, which are basically concept art, and hidden poems, which are foreshadowing the story. Not necessary, but certainly fun to hunt down. Notice how I said this is mainly a puzzle game. There are little combat breaks in the game that seem to separate puzzles, which is a welcome addition. However, they lead to a problem within the mechanics of the game and they’re why I can’t recommend playing this with three players (on Classic). To properly explain, however, I have to address the levelling system. It’s quite simple: pick up 50 hidden doohickeys and you level up, gaining a skill point for your account that can be used for either Amadeus, Pontius or Zoya. Amadeus will be able to create more objects, Pontius mainly gains combat abilities and Zoya gains different kinds of arrows that can assist in both utility and combat. As a result, Amadeus will not be very useful during combat, while Pontius and Zoya will be very useful (especially Pontius). The problem here is not quite Amadeus: it’s Pontius.See, the bulk of the game is puzzle-based, so Pontius can’t really do much but stand around and wait for the others to clear the way to the next battle. Furthermore, his special ability (breaking rocks and wood) becomes obsolete as soon as Zoya gains explosive arrows, which are much more flexible since a lot of the hidden EXP bottles are hidden up high. Therefore, the player stuck with Pontius (in a 3P Classic situation) would be mostly useless and Amadeus finds himself helpless during battle (he can help, but not as much as the others). As a result, I found that playing with two players, one dedicated to Amadeus and one dedicated to Zoya, led with the most satisfying game experience as we could switch to Pontius whenever needed instead of having deadweight with us. We didn’t even need to get Pontius’ skills until Zoya (for me) and Amadeus (for my friend) had all their skills unlocked.While the game is very, very forgiving (except, I’m guessing, on Hardcore), having lots of checkpoints that fully heal every character as often as you wish, there are still some annoyances (provided you don’t mind how forgiving the game is, which I didn’t). This mainly comes with the few ‘boss’ battles that appear throughout the game. They always take the same form: a big goblin with a massive club. Furthermore, this goblin kills anyone in a single hit and takes a fair bit to kill compared to other enemies, which is quite annoying. Also, I can’t imagine fighting the last boss in single player, though it’s a great fight where, once again, Pontius isn’t very useful.Visually, the game is actually pretty stunning, being very colorful. Lots of shadows and lighting make the game ‘pop’ and seem alive. You can clearly see everything on the screen even when it’s dark, which I feel is crucial in a puzzle game as the main challenge shouldn’t be finding the pieces, but figuring out how they fit into one another. The music is also very pretty, being very soothing most of the time and kicking up the tempo and intensity when needed. However, none of the songs really stick in your head, instead blending into an immersive soundscape. The whole game, being a playable fairytale, has a delightful cartoony feel to it, from the character designs to the story to the sounds and visual design. While the shallow combat seems a little tacked on and only created to give Pontius a purpose, the combat scenes are so short that it shouldn’t be counted as a huge negative. I would highly recommend this game for 2P coop players and cautiously recommend it for 3P coop players and single players, as I feel the former would leave one player bored (assuming they play on Classic, as Unlimited is simply too easy as far as I’m concerned) and the latter feels like it’s missing something. The game isn’t too hard either, making it perfect for both casual and hardcore players, though it does seem more casual. Nevertheless, it’s a nice little game that’s definitely worth your time.Do note, however, that the trailer (quite sadly) shows more of the DLC than the game itself. I’ll edit this when my friend and I get through the DLC, but know that it’s like a sequel (or a part 2) to the game; Trine 2 itself has 13 chapters and the DLC adds 7, to give you an idea. Who knows, maybe my complaints are fixed in the DLC?

content:
