												Frozenbyte did it again, best 2D/3D sidescrolling platformer become the bestest!if you haven't play Trine before, you should be, the story about those 3 hero hook up with Trine 2.but if you just skip the first one it's not a big deal tho, not much different. Trine Reviewhere my review link for Trine, since there's not much different for the second Trine, Trine review still legit for this one.I'll just review the different between those 2, I differentiated it to positive and negative, since it's my opinion you may not agree with me with some points. here it is :+ New type of puzzle, not like the first one that concentrate on destroying, opening gate with lever, grappling platform to platform. In Trine 2 really test your cunning eyes and sense, play with waterfall, bubble, and else!+ Removal of floating triangle is a beast, now it's not a Thief-centered-puzzle-solving anymore since Zoya can't grapple to any of Wizard hand made box or planks.+ Pontius got a big buff and become more dependable in fight and puzzle solving, now he can jump farther with charge jump, and range attack with throwing hammer.+ Amadeus now can levitating enemy, so now he can be used for fighting while Zoya or Pontius not available. It's a big buff for him, not like on the first Trine, when your attacking hero both dies you'll ♥♥♥♥ed up if surrounded by enemy with Amadeus.+ Despite of increase damage of fire arrow, level 2 skill give Zoya explosion, it's a good nerf altogether with buff, it's done a little improved damage and makes take down enemy from afar much more harder.+ Reworked fire arrow projectile and damage. damage now based on how long you stretched your bowstring, not just 2 spam fire arrow attack can kill almost everything. and the fire arrow projectile now same like normal arrow, not boosted speed like before.- The first thing you'll notice is there's no Energy consumption in Trine 2, so there's no energy vial to be sure. In my opinion, removal of energy consumption makes this games a little bit easier. apparently, you can use unlimited fire arrow and levitating.- Zoya can't shoot grapple below 45degree shooting angle, it's a little bit annoying. whilst in Trine you can shoot below that point- removal of individual skill points, em-em, yes it makes the entire gameplay of Trine 2 become harder, you may not miss every single exp vial since gaining skill point is a tough job.- There's no equipable item anymore in Trine 2, so you can't modify each hero more farther just like before. I really don't understand why they remove this feature. Now hidden boxes just give you secret, artwork, or piece of letters. d'oh.TL;DRBest 2D/3D platformer I've ever played! the gameplay, story, graphic, it all absolutely perfect.It is obviously better than Trine, but that not makes you skip the first one, since they offer you different type of puzzle (not much).

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I liked this game its fast paced and easy on the eyes, there were some challenges along the way, but with the power of friendship and team work we managed to beat it.Its Hitch's most briskly entertaining movie, and one of his most comic, adventure-caper type movies, largely thanks to the persona of Cary Grant. But its also one of his most suspenseful - in the fact that Grant is being recognised as someone else, and that he may be put in jail for someone else's crime.I've finally come to realise just how great This game is. The reason you should love Hitchcock is he put entertainment upfront. Hitchcock was not interested in whether this or that would happen in real life: he was interested in what would make the most entertaining scene for the movie. Trine 2 is a peak in this regard. The dialogue and situations intentionally throw reality to the wind - the double-entendre dialogue in the love scenes is not supposed to be the way people talk!If you said to Hitchcock "as if he'd keep driving" or "as if she'd do that"he would just laugh at you and say you've missed the point. This is 100%movieland, and once you get used to the fact, and that this is not a fault in the film, but done intentionally, you'll love it. Its expressionistic - everything happens in movie language: the people laughing at Grant in the elevator, the way he keeps driving drunk near the beginning, the way he grabs the knife and everyone stares at him after someone's been stabbed.It flirts with the idea of identity. I thought it was interesting how Grant first is dismissing, then incredulous that people should be calling him by another name; then, as the tries to find out who this guy is, he enters the hotel room of this new identity, then he puts the suit on, and finally he identifies himself as George Kaplan.A succession of fantastic, memorable scenes, a great leading man in Grant, and one of Hermann's essential Hitch scores make for a movie i can put on at any time.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												Trine 2 is less of a sequel, and more radical cosmetic surgery. Frozenbyte have exploded the formula into a beautiful, rainbow-sodden spectacle. You don't realise how few purple and green crystal-lit caverns there are out there, until you're forced to stop and bask in one. Trine is a fairytale platforming adventure, based around a magical floating sconce that's bound together the souls of a wizard, a knight and a thief. The story itself is sweet enough – perfectly charming and a shade too earnest – but what really drives you, beyond the irresistible instinct in platformers to travel to the right, is the satisfaction that's gained from solving the inventive physics-based puzzles. Playing solo, you can swap between characters instantly as you require their different skills. The Wizard can levitate objects, conjure boxes, and eventually planks, allowing him to bridge gaps and create steps. But he's all wizardy and crap in a fight, so tap him out when goblins and bosses appear. The Thief can fire a grappling hook and swing from wooden surfaces, and her bow makes her the best ranged fighter. Then there's the Warrior, who dishes out the melee damage with his sword, deflects lava with his shield, and smashes delicate stuff from afar with his hammer. If you've played the first game, you'll be thinking “well, this sounds pretty familiar. Shouldn't you be focusing on the new stuff?” The weakest thing about Trine 2 is how broadly identical it is to the first game. The energy bar has gone, and there's online co-op play, but Trine 2 amounts to a skill reset and a bunch of gorgeous new levels. The flexibility of the puzzles and the overlapping powers mean that often there's no pure, one-way solution. In particular, the Thief's agility becomes less essential as the Wizard learns to conjure more simultaneous objects. Solo, this doesn't matter. Multiplayer changes the nature of the game. First off, and this is such a superficial observation that I feel obliged to say it in a stupid way, it's nice to do a solve on a puzzle with a friend. The first Trine had local multiplayer, bizarrely hidden in a sub-sub-menu, but Trine 2 brings it to the main menu, and adds online matchmaking and text chat. It's now easy to drop into a game with strangers or pals. More fundamentally, dividing the powers between three players, instead of one player swapping between the powers as he sees fit, means that progress that could only previously be made by one character now has to be achievable by all three. Frozenbyte have addressed this in two ways. Firstly, the Wizard can levitate items that he's standing on in multiplayer. But life's too easy with a magic carpet. A more elegant solution is Unlimited mode. Tucked away in the 'host a game' options, this allows multiples of each class on screen. It's more chaotic, more flexible, and more fun. It solves some huffier moments, like when the Thief realises she's a complete spare wheel. And that moment where the Wizard decides to avoid a boss fight, hanging out by the partner-regenerating checkpoints while an endless stream of Thieves and Knights do the work. Trine 2 may retread a lot of old ground, but it's beautiful. It's like Frozenbyte are saying “Oh, did we make Trine? We meant this.” The same moderate puzzling challenge, the same characters, the same charm and some problems fixed.

												If you enjoy playing with your friends puzzle games that require teamwork and would also love to see beautiful colorful graphics, boy do I have the game for you! Trine 2(and soon Trine 1 the enchanted edition) will satisfy both of these needs of yours.The story of Trine and Trine 2 are not connected, so even if you have not played Trine 1 you dont really miss out anything other than a great game, storywise you miss nothing. :)In this game you will control 3 different characters(the same ones you used in Trine 1) Zoya the thief, Pontius the knight( and Amadeus the wizard. Each one of these chracters have their own unique abilities that are all needed in the puzzle that you will encounter in the game.A little bit about the characters:Zoya: she offers ranged attacking with her arrows(which you can enchance once you gain some levels) and great amount of utility with her hookPontius: he is more of the "its time to fight" character with his hammer(which can be thrown but its very slow!) and sword & shield combo. He will gain later on a little bit of utility as well but, that is once you gain some levels.Amadeus: he offers a great deal of utility. His main ability is to create magical boxes you can jump on to, naturally you will learn to create differnt kind of things when you gain more levels. Amadeus is the only one who can not harm enemies with his abilities alone.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Trine 2 has easily earned its rightful place as one of my favourite videogames of all time. Absolutely gorgeous, fairly intelligent and easy to play, the game is eye candy through and through. The mechanics are fun to manipulate and I love the fact that levels can't be solved with just one way in most cases. Another aspect of the game I thoroughly enjoy is the voice acting. It's pretty obvious that the game is meant to appeal to a younger audience as well, but it still manages to avoid cheesy liners, instead delivering clever dialogue and amusing conversations. If you're looking for something relaxing that looks and sounds good do yourself a favour and buy Trine 2.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Trine 2 is a pretty fantastic 2D puzzle-side scroling/platformer. Don't judge me by my playtime, since I already  play the first one for a decent amount of time, and I must say that Trine 2, stays true to the original while improving every aspect from the first one.  Beautiful graphic and clever , well thought mechanic is the strong point of Trine 2 (also 1).Story (9/10)Since I just play a small amount of time on this game and haven't got at least a quarter of the journey yet, I leave this one mostly at 'pending'. You probably ask why I give it a 9, its solely because of the excellent, bedtime-fairy tale story narrative, the narrator is just plain amazing. And I really look forward for the rest of the story, so far it has an excellent main pot, setting, and pace.Graphic (11/10)For a 2D side scrolling, Trine and Trine 2 offer a very distinct art style and stunning background, lifelike, and capture the fantasy setting perfectly. The graphic is the first thing that caught my attenttion to this game. I'm not  a fan of 2D platformer with 3D background, hell.. I find most of the background-character combination is just bland and dull, I'd rather play a full 2D platformer. But Trine manages to do it flawlessly. No or really rare platformer treat your eyes  like this. The set pieces are also varied, atleast until now, but I can see the creativity in there, I bet I'll see many more gorgeous places as I go through. It's purely beyond amazing. Gameplay (10/10)Balanced, well thought, unique, diverse, and clever. I like on how you solve the puzzle, its not 'linear', with 3 characters available, you can choose a variety of ways to solve the puzzles. The map layout is one of the best layout I've ever seen in a platformer-puzzle game. Also, this game make an intellegent use of its physic. Overall its fun and of course challenging without being unreasonable / over the top. What I meant with "over the top" is in many puzzle game (not only platformer), the puzzle is like..complicated, complicated in a way that its breaking the fourth wall, I mean..when I solve the puzzle, I was like..uhh..really? Trine didn't fal lto that category, the solutions are logical. If I can name other game, it'd be Portal 2, the same unique concept with 'ordinary but creative' problem solving method.Music (9/10)Another game which has an amazing soundtrack, when I can say a game OST is amazing? Its when the soundtrack is well placed and help to set out of the mood. Conclusion (9/10)Apart from the story, its a great game so far, I'm looking forward to find another great places, puzzles, and when the story unfold. Stunning graphic, awesome music, and consistently great gameplay and puzzles are the reasons why I could give a high score on my really early review.P.S: I probably won't review Trine 1, since Trine 2 is a much improved version of Trine 1, so my review will be the same for both game anyway.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												This is a game for you if you like platforming and lite puzzle solving. The game also features very stunning visuals throughout the entire playthrough. Most of the level backgrounds are impressive and give the platforming layout a nice sense of depth.Hard difficulty is recommended as the various traps can be run through in easy and medium difficulties without taking much damage. In hard difficulty you usually die instantly if you try to run through the traps like a headless chicken.Online co-op is available for maximum of 3 players which I highly recommend as every character has their distinctive (and important) roles to play. The character roles also become more apparent when you play co-op as you can't swap between the characters (like in offline) as you please (if you disable the option), but need to work together to overcome the obstacles. Plus, it's always funny when someone screws up and as a result the whole group dies instantly.The three playable characters are wizard, knight and thief.Wizard can conjure various metallic platforms to jump on and is especially useful to reach some of the very hard to reach places. He also has a cute wizard's hat which usually flies off hilariously when he dies.Knight has a shield + sword combo for defence, and to assist the wizard with platform creation he can magnetize the shield. Knight can use the shield to glide through the air like Mary Poppins.Knight also has a big hammer which he can use to bash enemies and break wooden objects.Thief is the nimble one as she can use grappling arrows to swing from wooden surface to another. She also has few stealth tricks to confuse the enemies, and can create low gravity bubble which comes in handy from time to time in co-op. In addition to normal arrows the thief can also shoot ice and fire/explosive arrows.The levels are scattered with experience bubbles and vials which are used to unlock all the abilities of the characters. In addition the levels feature treasure chests in various secret places which unlock poems and concept art that can be viewed from the main menu gallery.Checkpoints are frequent throughout the levels. Characters are healed (amount depends on difficulty) and resurrected at the checkpoints.Enemies are mostly goblins with various equipment like shields, spears and armour. The enemies drop experience and sometimes health pickups that heal every member of the party. Levels also have themed wild life which can both aid and hinder your progress.As a negative point the cutscenes cannot be skipped in multiplayer which isn't a problem in first playthrough, but can become tedious if you're planning to play it through more than once in co-op.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2013
												Veridict: 9.0This is an adventure sidescroller with graphics worth a best photography academy award, add this to a very fun gameplay with a constant change of roles between a Warrior, a Thief and a Wizard. The Trine show itself again and it's those three heroe's duty to discover why it is back and save the kingdom again.Choose Pontius, the warrior when you need an invencible wall and a mighty hammer throw to resist any harm and bring down any obstacle or threat on your path.Choose Zoya, the thief when you want to sneak past your enemies, swing through death pits, or kill anything with her explosive/frozen arrows.Choose Amadeus, the wizard when you need to solve puzzles that only his magic can help, create and build bridges and stairways to get to the next level or just imprisonate anyone who try to hit you.Every level is full of ferocious enemies and mindbreaking puzzles that makes you want to continue evolving your player skill to get to the end of this magical history. This is a must have for any fan of art, magic, challenge, and a good adventure.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Worth every penny. Every single scene in the game is like ♥♥♥♥♥♥s for your eyes. It's a pleasure just to sit for a second and admire the detail that went into every bit of the game. The multiplayer is unbelievably fun, with everyone trying to work together its choas but the best kind. The puzzles are challenging but not to hard that you get annoyed. The storyline isn't amazing but its sweet. The voice acting is enjoyable. The dialog is great with a few dirty jokes thrown in. The characters are great, and you'll fall in love with each of them. If you enjoyed Dust or Castle crashers you'll love this game! The only "Con" for me is I occasionally crashed, mostly when trying to host a multiplayer. But you can save at any time, and all-in-all I did not crash enough for it to really put me off. Loved it.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2012
												The Good: Online co-op (finally!). Scenery so colorful you may go blind (in a good way). Awesome puzzle platforming that doesn't restrict your options (there's usually two or more ways to solve the trickiest puzzles, and the simple ones always have more). Unlimited character play so you can co-op with up to 3 wizards if you want, then switch to 3 thieves or 3 knights if need be. The boss battle at the end of the game (which I won't spoil) is freaking epic!The Bad: The Wizard used to be able (in the first game) to conjure 7 boxes, 6 planks and a triangle that floated, was grappleable, and could be made to explode, now he only conjures a maximum of 4 boxes OR planks, and the triangle is sadly missing (this is partially solved by playing in Unlimited mode, as each copy of the Wizard can have their own stack of 4 objects).The Ugly: What "ugly"? This game is gorgeous!

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												As a newcomer to side scrolling genre, I was sceptical on how I will perceive the game on my point of view. This game was able to put my interest into any game that shares it genre. As for presentation, Frozenbyte shows us that this game is more than getting the character from the left side of the level to the right side of the level. Unlike any other games that sometimes can feel like chores playing them, this shows me otherwise. I was literally astonished by the beutiful background and some of the best ambient music in today's gaming.Apart from it's eye candy graphic and artwork, this game packed with the puzzle and gameplay. All of the puzzle that I encounter is not too hard but it requires some brain exercise on figuiring out which way is the best in cracking the puzzle. But, as the game progress, I found out that some of the puzzle can be easily bypassed by gravity field. It is not game breakiing, but it left me some bad taste in my mouth.In overall, this game set the bar high for any other games in side scrolling and platforming genre. I have tonnes of fun investing my hours into this game whether alone or with my best friend. Playing coop is highly recomended. If you guys into action fantasy type of game, this game is must owned.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												Trine 2 CS is an enchanting 2D side scroller game that steps into the realm of realism and jaw dropping graphics. Trine 2 bestow us with spectacular scenarios with ever changing level dynamics that shifts its paradigm with every level, the level of detail immerse you and binds you deeply into the game.Trine 2 offers gameplay that is far more challenging and enticing than the previous version - Trine2 is a far cry from its predecessor in all the department and completely sets the benchmarks when it comes to 2D side scroller games. The lush , vibrant and detailed environment grasp you and moves you towards it. The Goblin Menace DLC deserves a special mention since it takes the game to a whole new level both in term of variety and features - loaded with new abilities and off the charts looks this is perhaps the best DLC ever created for any game.Topped with brilliant music that soothes you and gels well with the game dynamics - the highs and low provide a perfect blend with the ever changing moments in the game. The really intriguing aspect of the game is the gameplay - a whopping 20+ hours of normal gameplay is not expected specially from an indie developer which obviously came as a surprise. You can stretch anywhere between 40-50 hours if you gunning for 100% achievements.Aside from few lackluster boss level (which is good but not groundbreaking ) and some minor glitches here and there - Trine 2 is a gamer delight - oozing with beautiful graphics, bright colour, great gameplay with ever changing dynamics and tactics makes the game a must have item in your game library. Here's hoping that the next installment will be even more challenging and gorgeous than ever.

												Buy that. Because its awesome and fun. You get to play (and swap if you want) one of three classic paper/rock/scissors characters - mage, warrior and thief. Mage creates and levitates items, warrior can bash things and thief can swing across on a rope and fire different elemental arrows.Each level is unique and insanely beautiful. With hand drawn backgrounds, secrets and amazing music this game has one of the best designs i ever saw.That said - it is rather short. There are however different difficulty settings for hardcore players and it does have some replayability, especially if you can find 2 other decent players.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Did you want yet more platforming adventures like the original Trine? To once again take on the role of the three intrepid hero’s on another adventure? Then this is definitely the game for you.This game is just stunning to look at. The backgrounds are designed beautifully and drag you into a fantasy world that just screams to be explored. Every level offers something new and exciting. With so many varied climates and locals this really does feel like an epic adventure, even more so than the original.This platformer took everything its predecessor did and multiplied it by 3. The gameplay is super fun, again like the first one there are always multiple ways to finish each challenge, whether it be by brute force or graceful finesse there is a play style to suit you. I loved the differences between each hero and how all their skills complimented each other. The story is great, it has far more depth than the original. With the clues as to what happened scattered throughout the adventure I was very eager to see its conclusion. Also with the addition of the complete story DLC another mini adventure awaits that is very enjoyable. From start to finish this title is phenomenal.I loved this game to no end. I don’t usually like platforming but this is just too good to pass up. Just the right amount of challenge. You would be a fool not to get this even at full price and now with the DLC included there is no excuse not to try this game. Just make sure to play the original one first, after all that game is great too.Have fun ^_^

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Trine 2 is everything the gorgeous, satisfying, and creative original Trine was, just a little greater. Each character has a greater selection of abilities which means a greater range of solutions to every problem. The greater number of levels each feel themselves greater: more entrancing, more extravagant, more epic. The storyline... hasn't changed much, which is to say that it still barely exists and that still suits the overall experience. There's no need to play this series in order as there's so little to miss. Even mixing levels from the later Goblin Menace expansion into the main campaign of the original wouldn't lead to much confusion, save for the loss of all those new abilities. The new highest difficulty, however, is noticeably more punishing than the original's, and sadly this isn't a good thing. Trine 2's Hard plus Hardcore setting has more of an effect on combat than any other aspect, which is by far the game's weakest feature. Trine is, after all, a puzzle game at its core and once established, it's difficult to make a puzzle harder without mucking it up with added complexity. And complexity isn't what Trine's about. It's about relatively simple people on a relatively simple quest acting creatively.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Trine 2 is undoubtedly the sequel Trine deserves. Stepping up and changing several things to make the game somewhat different than it's predecessor. Let's begin with the graphics, for a start. The back drops for each level provide each stage with variety. From lush green woodlands to a witches' home scattered with books, potions etc. Each stage is different and unique. Providing different puzzles and secrets to find. The puzzles are very similar to the first game. Using Amadeus the wizard to move blocks and Zoya to climb up to otherwise unreachable areas, and of course Pontius just killing stuff for the most part. The puzzles do sometimes have a certain level of challenge but for the most part can be solved by knocking heads with your friend(s) and working it out. As I mentioned in the previous review of Trine, this is undoubtedly a series that is best played friends, for the full experience. But if you do happen to be somewhat of a Billy no mates then you can play alone, which does however make the puzzle solving seem a little more difficult. The characters, as previously mentioned are the same as the first game;Zoya the Thief, Amadeus the Wizard and Pontius the knight all with their signature qualities. The level up system still exists as well allowing you to gain various useful abilities to help you solve particular puzzles or just kill enemies quicker. The characters themselves also seem fairly three dimensional, in terms of personality, compared to the first game. Pontius is a kind hearted yet fairly clueless knight. Zoya is a strong willed thief and Amadeus is a fairly cowardly wizard, who at times comes across as a bit of a perv too.Trine 2 is definitely worth a look if you've played the previous iteration of the series or enjoy the challenge of platforming and puzzling. A wonderfully looking game and definitely worth a look. Good Day!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												You and your friends are in a puzzling situation, as there are plants shooting straight upwards in a big gap infront of you, you say to your friend, playing as the thief, "how should we cross without diing?" and he says "i have an idea" and he switches to the mage, he creates a block and tells you to jump on, you do so, and he slowly moves the crate across the map with his magic ability, once you are across, you switch to the mage, and he jumps on, letting you guide the block towards where you are.In this lovely little game, you will expierience much harder challenges, i just told this one because it was quick enough to tell. This game is truly boring in single player, make sure you have a friend to go along with you :) otherwise the expierience is boring, you can hold up to 3 players, and the server is non-hamachi, so anyone can make it. the graphics, even on lowest setting, look very beautiful and the music is amazing, and if you get its dlc Goblin menace you get a special ability along with the ones you already have, such as, for the thief who wields a bow, a special arrow that once it hits any solid area, will make a big bubble, anything in side the bubble expierences low gravity, this allows players to jump through the bubble and get a bit of a jump boost beause of the low gravity, the special for the knight is he can hold his shield over his head and use it as a glider, the wizard, or mage can magnetize the object he makes, so that he can make an airship, or a platform on a wall, AGAIN YOU CAN ONLY GET THESE THREE POWERS IF YOU DOWNLOAD THE DLC, the dlc also  comes with the complete pack, which happens to be on sale at the moment. Heres someting i love about trine 2, say you are hosting a private server, and you have the dlc, but your friend doesnt (this actually just happened in a match i was in, i had the dlc) what will happen is your friend cant unlock the special powers, but the one with the dlc can, this makes up for some interesting teamwork,magnitize this, low grav bubble that, fly across here.now here is how you unlock powers, you have to collect 50... gems, we will call them, once you collect 50 gems you get one lvl up point, you can use that level up point on abilities. the most points it takes to unlock the ability that requires the most, is 4, and gems arent too rare, but i do suggest trying to get every one you see, the abilities are VERY helpful, maybe you need to solve something so you an get over a wall OR unlock the low gravity bubble and just jump over it, you need to take advantage of the abilities you unlock, they are helpfull.If you seriously read all that, feel free to friend me, and congratulations for being awesome, you diserve  this :)http://www.pinterest.com/pin/341851427934625882/

												This game (much like its predecessor) is a pure masterpiece, and I am convinced that it will be considered as a classic, in the years to come.So, what is it all about? Well, the game combines standard puzzle-platforming with some "Lost Vikings meets physics" elements. This is more than enough to get your attention, but Trine franchise doesn't stop there.Graphics, sounds, voice-overs and overall atmosphere in this game are absolutely brilliant. It oozes with "fairy tale feeling", so the end result feels like interactive story.To put it short, buy this game (along with the original Trine), because you will enjoy every minute of it!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
-Quick Review-Trine 2, is a 2D platformer that combines three different heroes into one (if you’re playing single player) or select one hero and work with two or three friends to try to complete the various puzzles in the game.-Detailed breakdown review-Story:  You are summoned by the Trine (A mysterious Dwarven object), which links a Wizard “Amadeus” , a Knight “Pontius” and a thief/entrepreneur “Zoya” together to save the kingdom. The story itself is put together like a bed time story, very straight forward and amusing to listen to.Game Play: (note, at this time 06/20/14 – I have not played the original Trine) As has been hinted above in the story section, you can switch between three very different heroes. You can actually complete the levels without switching at all, but generally switching makes solving puzzles much easier.There is a little bit of combat where you need to smash in some Goblin heads, but the most challenging aspect of the game is the environments which are definitely out to kill me. Plenty of death holes in the ground.There is also a quaint leveling system in the game, when you collect “experience orbs” you level up and are given a skill point to assign to a character and ability. By upgrading skills you make puzzle solving much easier and often times dynamic. I’ve solved puzzles with Amadeus’s boxes that I could have done faster and easier the “correct way”. But that aspect gives the game a sense of freedom.Multi-player:  I had the privilege to play this game with a friend, and let me say this game is amazingly more fun to play with one or two friends. The difference is that if you are playing with others, you are limited to which character you play as. If you’re playing with just one friend, which leaves one free character either of you can switch or rotate with. (For us, it was Pontius… Sorry buddy, you’re good at fighting, not at plat forming). Achievements: Here’s the basic break down for the achievements: Collect all the things, Find all the things, Do a few special things with each character, then Beat the game on Hard core mode on Hard difficulty, and you’ll have all the achievements.The game has 97 achievements, I was surprised that a game like Trine 2 had so many achievements, but it provided a great deal of entertainment and a fair bit of replay-ability to get the rest of the achievements.Price: The price for Trine 2 is $19.99. I played 30 hours (and that will increase as I work on getting the hard core achievements) that is a pretty fair price for how much time I’ve put into it. Good news though! We are in the Steam Summer sale (06/20/14)! The game is on sale right now for 85% off, in other words the game is $2.99 That is a great deal, if you’ve been wanting to play a platformer puzzle fantasy game, now is your time. You have until June 30th to get it at this current price.If you’re still not sure if you’d like to play it or not, you can also download a demo to test out first; you can’t be persuaded anymore than that. Conclusion: I really enjoyed the game. If you’re just looking to relax and play a fantasy adventure game, I highly recommend this game. It was fun to play, not overly difficult however the Hardcore kicked my butt; it’s not something you’ll just waltz through. But the easiest difficulties make the game seem very friendly.

content:
Posted: January 16
												WOW! What an improvement over the first one!Mostly pros and a few cons.Pros:- The first game was stunning and this just blew me away with how much it improved over the first game - It has better puzzles- More level traversing mechanics that work REALLY well- More character skills that are easier to execute- No mana (this was mostly superfluous in the first game)- Enemy battles are more engaging- Much more fluid controls  > Using the Rogue's grappling hook to get on to a platform from underneath is much easier > The ability for my character to make it onto a platform with a jump is much more lenient > Easier to summon and destroy things with the Wizard (quick squiggle = box, botched line = plank (yay) instead of box (boo), which was frustrating from the first game)- I can read the narration and skip faster to get into the level as a resultCons:- The only thing they haven't improved from the first game is that the Rogue needs a grappling hook aim when using a controller as she often latches onto the wrong platform or the wrong part of a platform. The grappling hook should also be able to retract further making it as easy as it should be to get on to platforms (despite that they somewhat improved this from the first game).- Things that are CLEARLY made of wood can't be grappled on to- Spiders sometimes spawn camp and this can become a little annoying- The camera is appalling in so many instances (normally too zoomed in) and it would be far better with a player controlled zoom function!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												Purchased this title on sale on a whim since it is co-op and it sat untouched in my library for a year(the Steam curse).  I finally got around to trying it out with a friend and I regret not trying it sooner.Pros:-Artwork is really stunning.-Puzzles are fun without being frustrating-Variety in the characters makes for a unique experience-Variety in level design with hidden areas abound.  Was very surprised at the level of exploration given the game's nature.-Co-op players aren't "screen-locked" to each other so you are free to explore above, below, and beyond your other mates.Cons:-Puzzles lean towards simplistic however working co-op with someone on them makes them enjoyable none-the-less-Controls are "okay".  At some points they are crisp and responsive but there are a few motions/jumps that feel a bit wonky.  While occasionally frustrating, not a deal breaker.  Have not tried with a gamepad, that might be part of the issue. -While there is no "screen-lock", if another player reaches a checkpoint bubble, you will be teleported to them no matter what you are doing.  Once realized it is fairly simple to avoid but some puzzles do not allow you to double back after being ported out.Trine 2 is a solid buy, particularly if you have friends to run co-op with.  The environment, story, and stunning artwork combined with crisp and exciting gameplay make it one of the best co-op platformers I have ever played.

												I was a huge fan of Trine1, the atmosphere, gameplay, music and puzzles were great. I was unsure how they could make Trine2 any better, Oh, how I was wrong. Frozenbyte did an amazing job with this new installment of the game. The game seems like art, it's very colourful with amazing background imagery while you're playing throughout the game, and the music fits right in. This is a very pretty game to play and be amazed. The way Trine2 is played is pretty much exactly the same as Trine1 with a little bit of differences, like the skill trees.COOP has been a lot of fun with 2 or 3 players. It can get a bit chaotic(and hard) if you're not working together and just missing around.If you played through Trine1 and enjoyed it, you will love this game. I would highly recommend picking up this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												A trine is a group of three. It was also a clever 2009 puzzle platformer starring a trio of adventurers, each with specific talents. Lucky us, now we have a sequel, Trine 2, that offers more fun physics-based challenges, more beautiful vistas, and adds online multiplayer to the mix.The first thing I noticed about Trine 2 is its stunning visuals. Each scene, from forests to caves to lazy beaches, shines with rich detail and startling lighting effects. There is always something amazing to distract you. Trine 2 easily makes for one of the prettiest games of the year.  If you played the first Trine, you'll find a very familiar game here. Players run from left to right through fantasy spectacles, surmounting obstacles and slaying a few goblins along the way. You have three heroes at your disposal: a wizard that can conjure blocks and platforms, a thief with a bow and grappling hook, and a knight with sword, hammer, and shield. The brilliance of Trine 2 is that it mostly leaves the choice of which hero to use up to you. I love it when a game lets me off my leash and tells me "have fun," -- and that's the kind of game Trine 2 is.It does fail to teach the player some important mechanics, though, resulting in slight exasperation when you don't realize a solution is even possible. The wizards platforms, for instance, can be stuck to swinging spiked maces, resulting in a pendulum conveyance. That's really cool, but it would have been nice to get a heads-up before I found myself stuck at the bottom of an ice slope for a little too long.When playing by yourself you switch between the three heroes at will. In a matter of moments you might slash through some goblins as the knight, switch to the thief to grapple to a high platform, then switch to the wizard to move a heavy block in front of a flame thrower. Trine 2 is also very friendly about multiplayer gaming, allowing up to three players to join the adventure either locally or online. I find the game becomes easier this way because you've got more than just one brain working on problems and you can multitask, but it's still satisfying.The few boss fights prove slightly disappointing. While visually impressive, they don't require the same thought as the rest of Trine 2. Merely crossing a chasm can be a real conundrum, but felling a giant beast is as simple as giving it a few whacks to its weak spots. I do love the way the bosses are foreshadowed early on in levels, though.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												TL;DR: You can't go wrong with this game and if it's on sale I recommend that you buy it at once!GRAPHICS:It has really beautiful graphics with a great attention to detail. I can't think of any platformer that could match Trine 2 at that.Look on youtube or at some screenshots to see the beauty that is Trine 2.GAMEPLAY:The platforming mechanics are well done, but it even get's better - since you have three playable character that you can switch at any time this means that you get three different playstyles: a wizard, a rogues and a warrior. The rogues and the warrior have some interesting tricks, but the wizard was the most interesting because it's quite different from what you usually do in a platformer. The wizard cannot shoot fireballs, but instead he can create boxes and planks or various sizes, move objects using telekinesis and do many other things. This makes solving the games puzzles even more interesting.MULTIPLAYER:If that isn't enough you can get two friends to play with you and make the game into a different, very enjoyable co-op puzzle solving and platforming experience.VERDICT:I definitely recommend this game to anyone that has even the slightest interest in it and if you don't look at some screenshots or video...and then buy this game! :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Steam sales have ruined me.I honestly forgot about this game because I had it on the back burner. I played 20 min, then switched to some other game I was dying to play after a steam sale, and then forgot about Trine 2. Never again. I'm so sorry Trine 2. You didn't deserve my neglect. But you were worth the wait.I seriously love this game. If you like platforming/puzzle games like Rochard, you will love this game. Granted, I have not finished it yet, but I had to stop mid game to say that I'm seriously impressed. This game offers the beautiful styling of a 2D platformer of the modern genre, yet offers a unique twist. There is an RPG element of leveling a class of character. And you get 3 primary characters to level and play at any given time. With 3 different classes to evolve and switch between at any given moment.... That's a mouthful. It sounds confusing but it's easy once you experience it. Lets say you have an enemy that is best suited to be taken down with brute force. Push left bumper, swittch to my brawler and take them down. 3 seconds later, I have a puzzle that requires some blocks to be moved around. Push left bumber, switch to my wizard. Move those blocks with my magic. 3 seconds later I have an obsticle that requires a finess jump. Push left bumper, switch to my archer/acrobat. Jump over that obsicle. It's really just fun. Pure and simple. If you like platformers. If you like modern, rich graphic, puzzle solving platformers, then I bet you will enjoy this game. I'll update this review after I finish the game... but so far I'm thoroughly impressed.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												The second installment of trinity: galactic expedia unleashed, breaks new ground in the gaming landscape. Trinity, or Trin for short is a tale about Duncon Stone, a recently rehabilitated drug addict recovering from severe trauma at an asylum in baltimore. Duncon, or dunk as the inmates call him was a former software engineer for microsoft but after raising a mutiny against steve jobs he was publically executed on the streets of johanesberg where he worked. What they didnt expect was that his corpse was exported to colombo where the doctors worked on him. they utilised various new implants and turned him into a man like machine called the Trine. Trine is a code name for the project, Transplant Ressurected infantry of new Eden. New eden is a bioengineering cartel that spans oceanic borders that funnels billions of dollars worth of biotechnology and unlicensed equipment into key geographic areas. The TRINE project is an attempt to create a global po-lice force designed to implement a new regime once individual governments topple following an expected economic collapse post global financial fiasco. As a Trine unit you are subordinate to your task master, some inglorious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who goes by the name of "the cammel's muel".  CM is what the guys in the lab call him, but to Duncan stone he is the epicentre of a world of suffering under his rule. CM send you all over the globe doing secret missions to merge and consolidate important equipment under his roof. On one uneventful escort mission to secure a new type of balistics device, Duncon gets hit by the typical natural disarster employed in all games these days, you guessed it.. lightaning!. that's right, he takes a bolt to the head which fries the inhibitor chip that CM daddy uses to control him. But the other players know this. and they're coming for you. The game then turns into its multiplayer feature here, which is essentially a treadmil of experiance grinding in order to gear up for the boss fight back in the New eden facility. Its very uninspired and doesent add much to whats already out there in terms of Trinity's mian competitors, namely farming simulator 2000 and football manager 2014. In any case you get some cool guns and the matchmaking system is okay. Once youre geared up you get to face off against the cammels muel in an all star battle of the ages. We're back to single player here now guys just for the record. after a grindy battle of tearing down his health and toking up on heal potions through the entire fight you eventually kill him. Unfortunately for stone, the facility does actually explode trapping him in the compartment underneath. THe game ends with duncon stone putting himself into cryosleep since he is faced with no other alternitive. This sory arc therefore is the prequel of Demolition Man, which aired in the 80's. Overall, not a bad film. Demolition man had some cool plot twists and the actor played the part well. 4/10 in terms of special effects, the 80's dont really compare to where we are today. Either way, if youre keep to tune into some good old fashioned film, Demolition man is the way to go.Until next time, stay snazzy!

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Not only a game that I played with my girlfriend (and that I could play with my girlfriend in the first place), but one that gave an equally good, fun and fullfililng experience for the both of us. We enjoyed every moment of it, working together solving interesting (not frustrating) puzzles, jumping around in one of the best looking game environments I have ever seen; and the co-operative aspect of lending each other a hand where neededI cannot make statements about the solo experience of this game. However, if you have someone in mind/have someone you want to play a game with, this easily is a no-brainer. I am sure you will not regret it. We like it so much we are planning on going back to the first trine because we wanted more and will buy trine 3 whenever it releases. Coming back to trine 2 if you are looking for a great a co-operative experience in a perfectly designed world and don't mind doing some thinking, besides the jumping and fighting; this is the game for you. Pro's:- Amazing world- Interesting puzzles- Great co-op- Cool character dynamics- Almost perfect mix platform/puzzle/fight elementsCon's:- Average at best story (dont play it for the story)- No tactical aspect within fighting; feels like a (thinking/puzzle) layer could be addedGrade: 8,5 (must own within this genre)Part of DoubleR's Hall of Exceptional Games (DHEG)DoubleR's Mark of Originality

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Coming off it's success of Trine, Trine has lost none of it's glamour, and in the process has added only everything wonderful. I really enjoyed the first trine. It's story, music, gameplay, all of it was generally delightful, allbeit short. Trine 2 follows wonderfully in it's footsteps.Here we find our three heroes not really looking for adventure per say, but the Trine once again find it for them. This time they are taken off to save a world of enchantment and a battle between sisters. In the process they find themselves fighting goblins. There is no reason to argue with story line here, as the story is short, succinct, not complicated, and enjoyable for the game. In terms of gameplay, Trine 2 builds on it's predecessor, working out many of the physics kinks that were so lauded. The characters do basically the same thing, with the addition of a few extras - the knights glide, and magnet shield, the thiefs special gravity arrow, and ability to hide herself, and the wizards magnetic objects, and ability to trap enemies inside boxes, as well as ability to pick up enemies. All in all, the gameplay of this game is smooth and for the most part without problems. 9.5/10In terms of graphics, Trine 2 looks superb. The artists who worked the concepts of this game have done a phenomenal job yet again. The colours, the look, and the increased depth make this side-scroller look even better. The graphics themselves could be a little nicer, sharper, and slightly more realistic in some areas - the characters for instance - but all in all this game is more than pleasing on the eyes. 9/10Music in this game is one thing that I really enjoy. The embience coupled with the wonderful sound track is above par. Music is a lost art when it comes to video games sometimes, but Trine 2, like it's predecessor, does an excellent job of creating wonderful atmosphere and putting the right music at the right time. And just add in here, the narration of Trine 2 is just as fun as the first. 9.5/10 (BTW, I'm a music teacher)Co-op is such a hard thing to get right. It's hard to know when it's too much, or when it's not enough. It's a good thing that co-op over the internet was added to this game. It makes it so much more fun to play that way. The only drawaback to this games co-op is the same as last times, the controller configuration. More often then I would like to admit, the control configurations seem to be out of wack. Responding to the wrong thing, or not working at all. Multiple keyboards is still an impossible task sometimes. The co-op itself is fun to play with friends, but if the work on controller configuration were fixed the co-op would be even more fun. 8.5/10Overall, this game is wonderful. It can be short, or long, depending on what you plan to do with it. It can be easy, or you can challenge yourself, as I have, to find new ways to beat certain areas. If you find it too easy, put it in hardcore mode, on hard, then give it a whirl. Enjoy the colours, the embience, and try and find a friend to play this game with you. You won't win any major tournaments while shooting dozens of people, but you will find yourself enjoying the fact that you've made it through a game using your brain. Trine 2 - 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Trine 2 is a 2-D puzzle platform game. Unlike games like Braid and Vessel, there are multiple ways to solve each puzzle. Overall it is a lot of fun, there is a good mix of thoughtful puzzle solving and fast-twitch action and platform jumping. There are three characters with different abilities. Most puzzles are obviously designed for one character, but in a lot of cases you can solve them with multiple characters. It is fun to figure out the "knight" solution to a "wizard" puzzle. Also, there are additional challenges in addition to progressing through the game: experience pickups and chests. You can win extra achievements by getting all the experience pickups and chests for a level. There is a decent amount of replayability, although I had enough playing it through once. There are an obscene number of achievements available for this game, overkill if you ask me. There is a lot of content here, I have played ~19 hours so far without going back to replay any of the levels to pick up more achievements. The background graphics are very pretty and imaginative, althoug they obscure things sometimes. Overall I can recommend this game as a fun 2-D puzzle platform game, with a low price and tons of content.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												Purchased this title on sale on a whim since it is co-op and it sat untouched in my library for a year(the Steam curse).  I finally got around to trying it out with a friend and I regret not trying it sooner.Pros:-Artwork is really stunning.-Puzzles are fun without being frustrating-Variety in the characters makes for a unique experience-Variety in level design with hidden areas abound.  Was very surprised at the level of exploration given the game's nature.-Co-op players aren't "screen-locked" to each other so you are free to explore above, below, and beyond your other mates.Cons:-Puzzles lean towards simplistic however working co-op with someone on them makes them enjoyable none-the-less-Controls are "okay".  At some points they are crisp and responsive but there are a few motions/jumps that feel a bit wonky.  While occasionally frustrating, not a deal breaker.  Have not tried with a gamepad, that might be part of the issue. -While there is no "screen-lock", if another player reaches a checkpoint bubble, you will be teleported to them no matter what you are doing.  Once realized it is fairly simple to avoid but some puzzles do not allow you to double back after being ported out.Trine 2 is a solid buy, particularly if you have friends to run co-op with.  The environment, story, and stunning artwork combined with crisp and exciting gameplay make it one of the best co-op platformers I have ever played.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Trine 2 is a gorgeous physics-based 3D platformer, and it’s meant to be experienced with friends. The most important difference from the original Trine is that this game supports three-player co-op over the internet. It may seem like a "well, duh" feature, but it makes a world of difference over the previous local-only game.By building on its successes rather than messing with its entertaining gameplay, Trine 2's simple concept of trekking toward the right side of the screen feels more like an otherworldly adventure than just another platformer. The abilities of your three playable characters - Wizard, Rogue, and Warrior - synergize superbly. Though at times you may feel overly dependent on another character's unique skills, the often misplaced trust you put in your friends’ talent will generally lead to hilarious and unintended successes. Frequently, the way to figure out a puzzle is to throw yourself at it until you discover a solution. A side-effect of this is death, but thankfully, it’s hardly a penalty. As long as one character remains alive and makes it to one of the many checkpoints in a level, the others are instantly revived. If everybody dies, all progress is saved and everybody is reincarnated at the latest checkpoint. This serves the flow of the game well, because your sense of adventure is never punished; indeed, being practically immortal in a platformer is surprisingly fun!Don’t expect much from the story; other than giving a reason to run to the right, it exists only to provide context to Trine 2’s challenges and puzzles. The reward for figuring out each scenario is mainly a sense of progression – but it works. Progression could mean accumulating experience potions that grant each character improved skills or new abilities, or it could mean discovering hard-to-reach chests that contain pieces of concept art or a narrated stanza from the main antagonist’s journal. Simply getting to the next level is often reward enough, because this game’s vibrant visuals are stunning.Trine 2's artistic merit is absolutely jaw-dropping. The title screen alone sets the bar for the rest of the game. (Try starting the game at different times during the day!) Half of my play-time was spent taking in the stunningly beautiful backdrops and set pieces. I felt guilty when I solved a puzzle without fully admiring the obscene amount of effort put into the graphical presentation of this game. The quality is consistently superb - worthy of your attention all the way through to the last chapter - and every shade of the rainbow gets a feature performance. The fun to be had in applying home-brewed solutions to solving puzzles with your friends is what sustains Trine 2 until its end. Along with constantly being rewarded with beautiful vistas and remarkably decorated interiors, finding all the hidden goodies will definitely tempt your inner completionist. Although you may need to set personal goals to warrant a second play-through, Trine 2 is a very entertaining game to play over a week with one or two of your friends.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												While not quite the masterpiece Trine 1 was, Trine 2 is still a very good game.The difficulty was lowered for some reason, which is a move I can't understand since the first one was too easy in my eyes. The characters are mostly the same - though they seem to have lost their mana bar, and some abilities too.The inventory is gone, and with it all the relics you could collect. Instead, you get artwork and poems in hidden chests.The levels are still as beautiful as before - and with the "complete story" edition they'll last you far longer than the original Trine did.All in all, it's more of the same - and since Trine 1 was so short and fun, I don't mind that one bit.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Trine 2 is a puzzle/adventure platforming game as ingenious as it is stunning. If you like puzzles, thinking outside of the box, and... bopping goblins? You will probably fall in love with Trine 2 in a heartbeat!Below is a list of attributes pertaining to Trine 2, and some personal opinion in regards to how they did.STORY: 4/10"Feels like it's missing something... Oh, yes! More goblins!"I'll give Trine 2 a cookie for being relatively unique compared to most other games. The execution is fine, though the game does leave you feeling like there should be more. Additionally, some aspects of the plot can be seen coming a mile away. Fortunately, there's at least one or two good twists in store. For the sake of spoilers though, I won't disclose them here. The story of Trine 2's is not one to be taken seriously.Of course, you weren't looking to play this for the story, were you?GAMEPLAY: 7/10"Think of it as a test of manhood. Or mousehood."Earning a few extra points for its fairly clever implementation of skills and the three heroes, Trine 2 really lets you play the game in your own style, be it through finesse, sheer force, or stuffing boxes into sacred places they clearly don't belong! If you get stuck at some point or confused, the narrator offers some clues on how to proceed. Compared to most games that babysit you along, this is much more preferrable.Admittedly, the controls do take a little getting used to, and even Normal Difficulty can be downright brutal if you're new to the game. Thankfully, a lot of the achievements (if you're OCD like I am) can be obtained without getting your rear end handed to you. Some are possible right at the main menu! *Hint, hint.*DESIGN: 10/10"No pixel was spared."Trine 2 is outrageously beautiful. Beautiful to the point of losing sight of your character on the screen! ... Seriously, this happened to me playing it. But that's okay because Trine 2 is a literal slideshow of eye candy and scenic splendor. Rewarding to watch just in its own right. Being able to play in it, let alone interact with it, is an added bonus.Perhaps the nicest part about its shiny graphics is that you don't have to cash in on your life insurance policy to make a system capable of running it. Even with a simple dual-core PC, Trine 2 runs magnificently at high detail.SUMMARY: 7 out of 10.Normally, I detest games that emphasize graphics since they usually have horrible gameplay and/or story about as in-depth as a piece of cardboard. Trine 2's storyline isn't the greatest, but it makes up for it in its unique and fluid style, gameplay, as well as the lovely panoramic scenes the game immerses you into. It's a game that isn't trying to sell you some epic story or brand-spanking new mechanic... It's just fun to play!

												An absolutely awesome game with beautiful graphic and completely stunning soundtrack. Where you play as one of three heroes (or as all of them if you are playing alone): Amadeus a wizard who can conjure boxes out of nothing, Zoya a thief with a grappling hook and a bow with a quiver full of arrows with special abilities, and Pontius a brave knight seeking worthy quests. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Let me first just say the obligatory fact that this game is BEAUTIFUL. Normally not something I would think of as a defining quality of a 2D puzzle game, but it... you just gotta play it yourself to see just how amazing this game looks. I suppose because it IS 2D, it runs great on lower end machines while being able to still stay beautiful.As far as gameplay, it is a fun combination of puzzle, platforming and combat elements. There are three characters each with a defining set of abilities that work brilliantly together. They aren't complicated, but when put together with the crafty environment it really just makes for a plain FUN game! I would reccomend getting a buddy to play it with sometimes as well. Maybe we have missed something, but the way the multiplayer seems to work is that basically someone will be able to "drop in" on someone's story and be able to go through it together. This becomes a problem because one of use ends up going back and playing through something again, but it isn't too terribly bad. You find there were different ways to solve puzzles and then have fun trying to naviate with anothe player (and enjoy the scenery of course!).So, yes I would reccomend this game! I was doubtful at first, but it has come together to be a very enjoyable game from all fronts. I haven't completed the story yet, but it introduces new mechanics and new environments enough that it dosen't become monotonous. Awesome game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Not only a game that I played with my girlfriend (and that I could play with my girlfriend in the first place), but one that gave an equally good, fun and fullfililng experience for the both of us. We enjoyed every moment of it, working together solving interesting (not frustrating) puzzles, jumping around in one of the best looking game environments I have ever seen; and the co-operative aspect of lending each other a hand where neededI cannot make statements about the solo experience of this game. However, if you have someone in mind/have someone you want to play a game with, this easily is a no-brainer. I am sure you will not regret it. We like it so much we are planning on going back to the first trine because we wanted more and will buy trine 3 whenever it releases. Coming back to trine 2 if you are looking for a great a co-operative experience in a perfectly designed world and don't mind doing some thinking, besides the jumping and fighting; this is the game for you. Pro's:- Amazing world- Interesting puzzles- Great co-op- Cool character dynamics- Almost perfect mix platform/puzzle/fight elementsCon's:- Average at best story (dont play it for the story)- No tactical aspect within fighting; feels like a (thinking/puzzle) layer could be addedGrade: 8,5 (must own within this genre)Part of DoubleR's Hall of Exceptional Games (DHEG)DoubleR's Mark of Originality

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Great game.  The story is a bit boring and you never really feel connected to the story or the characters, but the scenary is some of the best I have ever seen in a side scroller.  I played the first one, and I'm happy to say that the Wizard has been nerfed a bit.  It is now much harder to kill enemies with his boxes, but almost every puzzle can be solved with him still.  The game play is fun, but not too challenging, and the game is very forgiving since it puts spawn points after every puzzle, or even half way through a long one.  To sum it up, it is a great game to play with some friends and have a good time checking out the amazing scenery, but if you are just trying to find a good solo game with a good story, look elsewhere.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												i'll give this game a 9/10.  what this game is, is fun. its a bit challenging playing solo, though with 2 of your friends this game is the perfect amount of challenging to where you can just chill and talk to friends and play the game. graphics are obviously stunning, especially with sweetfx on, not much else i can say about them other than them being great.  many of the puzzles have multiple ways to be completed while playing with friends, many of those involve using your upgrades to kind of cheat the system, either way you end up with the same result. many of the bosses are quite underwhelming, most can be beaten in under 20 seconds, this is my only real complaint about the game.  just as the boss fights, the game isnt very long either, on a casual run with friends and all dlc included, i completed the game in about 10 hours.  the soundtrack is great, i could probably listen to it for fun.  theres some very small issues with the game, dead enemies stuttering occasionally, things like that (none of which are of any real concern to me.) overall its a great game and for the three dollars i paid for it on the steam sale, it was more than worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Not only a game that I played with my girlfriend (and that I could play with my girlfriend in the first place), but one that gave an equally good, fun and fullfililng experience for the both of us. We enjoyed every moment of it, working together solving interesting (not frustrating) puzzles, jumping around in one of the best looking game environments I have ever seen; and the co-operative aspect of lending each other a hand where neededI cannot make statements about the solo experience of this game. However, if you have someone in mind/have someone you want to play a game with, this easily is a no-brainer. I am sure you will not regret it. We like it so much we are planning on going back to the first trine because we wanted more and will buy trine 3 whenever it releases. Coming back to trine 2 if you are looking for a great a co-operative experience in a perfectly designed world and don't mind doing some thinking, besides the jumping and fighting; this is the game for you. Pro's:- Amazing world- Interesting puzzles- Great co-op- Cool character dynamics- Almost perfect mix platform/puzzle/fight elementsCon's:- Average at best story (dont play it for the story)- No tactical aspect within fighting; feels like a (thinking/puzzle) layer could be addedGrade: 8,5 (must own within this genre)Part of DoubleR's Hall of Exceptional Games (DHEG)DoubleR's Mark of Originality

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												When I played Trine 1, I was in love with that game. Moving on to Trine 2, I feel I am sickly obsessed with this game. It made improvements in almost every imaginable way to an already perfect game. Characters have more diverse and interesting skills, there're a lot more secrets to uncover and the levels are ever more expansive and intriguing. And combat in general is a lot better because each character has more ways to deal with enemies.What I love Trine 2 the most is how each level feels very different from another, you have jungles, caves, deserts, snowy mountains, beaches, etc, essentially any imaginable environment you want to visit exists in this game, that great diversity combined with the game's amazingly charming visual shall guarantee one of the most pleasant experiences ever!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
												WOW! What an improvement over the first one!Mostly pros and a few cons.Pros:- The first game was stunning and this just blew me away with how much it improved over the first game - It has better puzzles- More level traversing mechanics that work REALLY well- More character skills that are easier to execute- No mana (this was mostly superfluous in the first game)- Enemy battles are more engaging- Much more fluid controls  > Using the Rogue's grappling hook to get on to a platform from underneath is much easier > The ability for my character to make it onto a platform with a jump is much more lenient > Easier to summon and destroy things with the Wizard (quick squiggle = box, botched line = plank (yay) instead of box (boo), which was frustrating from the first game)- I can read the narration and skip faster to get into the level as a resultCons:- The only thing they haven't improved from the first game is that the Rogue needs a grappling hook aim when using a controller as she often latches onto the wrong platform or the wrong part of a platform. The grappling hook should also be able to retract further making it as easy as it should be to get on to platforms (despite that they somewhat improved this from the first game).- Things that are CLEARLY made of wood can't be grappled on to- Spiders sometimes spawn camp and this can become a little annoying- The camera is appalling in so many instances (normally too zoomed in) and it would be far better with a player controlled zoom function!

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												A platformer puzzle level game, I must say Trine 2 is one of my favourites platformer games. How they are designed, how are the characters abilities, how you can gain completeness by collecting all items and how they improved the fights despite the first Trine. Ah, and of course, its awesome graphics and music. Absolutely recommended.I really enjoyed this 2nd Trine. Although that fact, since I first played and finished the first one it shocked me that there was no mana and that chests give draws and poetries instead of items that give you POWER OMG. Think about it. In Trine 1 I could summon 7 boxes and 3 surfaces with Amadeus. SEVEN BOXES. Now I only could 4, boxes or surfaces together.Though I have to say that the change they made about experiences and habilities compensated this "lack" of awesomeness. (i.e. With the Illuminati Triangle in Trine I completed several levels with my brother, I summoned it and he hooked on it xD)Also they hardened the puzzles and these ones were more tricky sometimes.The art is sublime as always and the music as well. I set the difficulty on Difficult, to make fights more entertaining. Indeed they were. Sometimes I died more than a couple of times. Perhaps I should try Hardcore mode. Who knows.Still, I also really didn't like some levels. I don't know, for example the Sewers' One. It was all so claustrophobical and I died many times, MANY.The Goblins DLC was perfect, I really enjoyed it (only the Giant Worm's one I hated). So I reccomend to take it as well and wait for a sale to buy Trine 1, 2 and DLC. Or only Trine 2 and DLC.Ah yeah, another thing I'd like to add, is that in Trine 2 there was finally a FINAL BOSS FIGHT. It was something that I missed in 1st one. That level was going up, kill normal enemies and that's all. Instead of that, in Trine 2 you have a properly final boss fight. It was hard xD

content:

PROS:+ awesome gameplay mechanics with 3 characters+ level design+ skils/powers of each character+ fairy tale story+ visual look+ online co-opCONS:- couple of bugs/glitches- removed items from first gameComment:A fantastic and gorgeous game, loads of fun when you play with your friends! It takes what Trine gave us and enhances it through online co-op and 20(!) levels. The enemies are more difficult this time but the gameplay still revolves around puzzle solving and obstacle removing/dodging. If you loved the first game you will love this. They even added various difficulties including Hardcore mode which does not let your characters respawn until you reach the next checkpoint. I can really recommend this game to both casual and hardcore gamers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Trine 2 is a puzzle/adventure platforming game as ingenious as it is stunning. If you like puzzles, thinking outside of the box, and... bopping goblins? You will probably fall in love with Trine 2 in a heartbeat!Below is a list of attributes pertaining to Trine 2, and some personal opinion in regards to how they did.STORY: 4/10"Feels like it's missing something... Oh, yes! More goblins!"I'll give Trine 2 a cookie for being relatively unique compared to most other games. The execution is fine, though the game does leave you feeling like there should be more. Additionally, some aspects of the plot can be seen coming a mile away. Fortunately, there's at least one or two good twists in store. For the sake of spoilers though, I won't disclose them here. The story of Trine 2's is not one to be taken seriously.Of course, you weren't looking to play this for the story, were you?GAMEPLAY: 7/10"Think of it as a test of manhood. Or mousehood."Earning a few extra points for its fairly clever implementation of skills and the three heroes, Trine 2 really lets you play the game in your own style, be it through finesse, sheer force, or stuffing boxes into sacred places they clearly don't belong! If you get stuck at some point or confused, the narrator offers some clues on how to proceed. Compared to most games that babysit you along, this is much more preferrable.Admittedly, the controls do take a little getting used to, and even Normal Difficulty can be downright brutal if you're new to the game. Thankfully, a lot of the achievements (if you're OCD like I am) can be obtained without getting your rear end handed to you. Some are possible right at the main menu! *Hint, hint.*DESIGN: 10/10"No pixel was spared."Trine 2 is outrageously beautiful. Beautiful to the point of losing sight of your character on the screen! ... Seriously, this happened to me playing it. But that's okay because Trine 2 is a literal slideshow of eye candy and scenic splendor. Rewarding to watch just in its own right. Being able to play in it, let alone interact with it, is an added bonus.Perhaps the nicest part about its shiny graphics is that you don't have to cash in on your life insurance policy to make a system capable of running it. Even with a simple dual-core PC, Trine 2 runs magnificently at high detail.SUMMARY: 7 out of 10.Normally, I detest games that emphasize graphics since they usually have horrible gameplay and/or story about as in-depth as a piece of cardboard. Trine 2's storyline isn't the greatest, but it makes up for it in its unique and fluid style, gameplay, as well as the lovely panoramic scenes the game immerses you into. It's a game that isn't trying to sell you some epic story or brand-spanking new mechanic... It's just fun to play!

												i'll give this game a 9/10.  what this game is, is fun. its a bit challenging playing solo, though with 2 of your friends this game is the perfect amount of challenging to where you can just chill and talk to friends and play the game. graphics are obviously stunning, especially with sweetfx on, not much else i can say about them other than them being great.  many of the puzzles have multiple ways to be completed while playing with friends, many of those involve using your upgrades to kind of cheat the system, either way you end up with the same result. many of the bosses are quite underwhelming, most can be beaten in under 20 seconds, this is my only real complaint about the game.  just as the boss fights, the game isnt very long either, on a casual run with friends and all dlc included, i completed the game in about 10 hours.  the soundtrack is great, i could probably listen to it for fun.  theres some very small issues with the game, dead enemies stuttering occasionally, things like that (none of which are of any real concern to me.) overall its a great game and for the three dollars i paid for it on the steam sale, it was more than worth it.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Let me first just say the obligatory fact that this game is BEAUTIFUL. Normally not something I would think of as a defining quality of a 2D puzzle game, but it... you just gotta play it yourself to see just how amazing this game looks. I suppose because it IS 2D, it runs great on lower end machines while being able to still stay beautiful.As far as gameplay, it is a fun combination of puzzle, platforming and combat elements. There are three characters each with a defining set of abilities that work brilliantly together. They aren't complicated, but when put together with the crafty environment it really just makes for a plain FUN game! I would reccomend getting a buddy to play it with sometimes as well. Maybe we have missed something, but the way the multiplayer seems to work is that basically someone will be able to "drop in" on someone's story and be able to go through it together. This becomes a problem because one of use ends up going back and playing through something again, but it isn't too terribly bad. You find there were different ways to solve puzzles and then have fun trying to naviate with anothe player (and enjoy the scenery of course!).So, yes I would reccomend this game! I was doubtful at first, but it has come together to be a very enjoyable game from all fronts. I haven't completed the story yet, but it introduces new mechanics and new environments enough that it dosen't become monotonous. Awesome game!
